description:
Draughts is a simulation of the game checkers built for the National Physical Laboratory's Pilot ACE. It was later ported to the Manchester Mark 1. The player could play against the computer whose moves were recorded on a teletype printer. The player had to use switches to select their move. There were two cathode ray displays showing the current state of the game and the current input. The input could be discarded if it was undesired.

When the program terminated, it played God Save the King through the mainframe's speaker.
title: Draughts

description: The Samuel Checkers-playing Program allows a player to play checkers against the computer. Later iterations on the game allowed the program to learn from past games and improve its game. It was a landmark program in the early development of artificial intelligence. The game was updated until the mid 70s and ran on various computers including the IBM 701, IBM 704 and IBM 7094.
title: The Samuel Checkers-playing Program

description: Robot Chess is an early chess game in which the user can play against an AI. The AI is only powerful enough to compute "mate-in-two" problems and thus the game didn't represent a full game of chess. Players would enter moves of the Ferranti Mark 1 and the computer would print out the response move. The simulation ignores some chess rules such as en passant, promotion and castling.
title: Robot Chess

description: OXO is a tic-tac-toe game that used one of the two displays of the EDSAC computer to display the game rather than the contents of the memory as was its purpose. The player would play against the computer which would play a "perfect" game. Input was given using a rotary telephone controller after which the screen was updated and the computer would take its turn.
title: OXO

description: The Craps Game on the MIDAC throws simulated dice in a game of craps until it has either won or lost. The results of the dice throws are printed out for the players and observers to see.
title: Craps Game

description: The Tick Tack Toe game on the MIDAC gave the computer some personality. The computer would print out "You cheated!" when the player tried to enter multiple crosses in a single turn, or print special characters to indicate swearing when it lost the match, immediately apologizing afterwards by saying "Bless your soul".
title: Tick Tack Toe

description: The Pool game on the MIDSAC allows players to shoot some pool. The 13 inch CRT display shows the position of the balls and the pool cue. The player can position the cue and take a shot after which the computer will compute the location and speed of each of the 17 balls and display their simulated trajectories on screen.
title: Pool

description: Carmonette (Combined ARms Computer MOdel) is an early Monte Carlo combat simulation used by the US military. It modelled combat scenarios for battalions and companies. Units can be ordered to move, prepare fire and fire. The simulation did not use a screen. The US military started using the software from 1956 onwards to study tank/anti-tank engagements and was followed up by multiple improved successors.
title: Carmonette

description:
System Training Project was a training computer constructed for the US Air Force that allowed users to train for operating Air Defense Direction Centers (ADCCs). ADCCs were centres where radar data on incoming aircraft was to be processed. The simulator was an almost complete replica of the actual system.

The user's task is to identify, pinpoint, and interdict. Instead of a display the computer used an IBM 407 printer to make a new print-out of the radar image each time it changed. The computer was later upgraded to include a film camera and CRT screen to display the information. A human team was required to administer the exercise and interpret the results.
title: System Training Project

description:
Hutspiel is a military training simulation for the Goodyear Electronic Differential Analyzer (GEDA) that simulates at a theatre level. Its intention was to study the use of tactical nuclear weapons and conventional air support in Western Europe in the event of a Soviet invasion.

The game pits two players against each other with one controlling NATO forces in France, Belgium and West Germany, and the other in control of a Soviet invasion force trying to penetrate a 150 mile frontage. Players could allocate forces across sectors of the map and set targets (such as airfields, enemy troops, supply depots and transportation facilities) for planes and nukes.

Early versions of the game would have the computer continue the simulation until it was paused for further input. In later versions the game used turns of fixed time increments. The game modeled troop reinforcement, resupply and movement by rail. It did not account for terrain or weather.
title: Hutspiel

description: The Bernstein Program is the earliest known chess game that implemented the complete rule set. The game examines two levels of moves, but unlike earlier chess games doesn't try out every possible move but only the seven most plausible moves. After determining what the most plausible moves are the game uses static factors and minimaxing to determine the best move. Running on the IBM 704 computer the program took about eight minutes to determine its move and never managed to defeat a human opponent.
title: The Bernstein Program

description: The Top Management Decision Simulation is an early "serious game". It's a computer assisted game that's used to train managers for decision making. The game models idealized business transactions. It was featured in the AMA Management Development Seminar and the Executive Decision Making Program.
title: The Top Management Decision Simulation

description: The Management Game is an early serious game. Its purpose is training students to be management executives for businesses. The game runs over the course of three years during which players must make the right decisions for one of three competing detergent companies. It received a major overhaul in 1986.
title: The Management Game

description: Tic-Tac-Toe on the TX-0 is a basic Tic-Tac-Toe game in which the player competes against the computer. The players enters their commands with a light pen.
title: Tic-Tac-Toe

description: Mouse in the Maze is played with the light pen. The player can create a maze by removing line segments on a 8x8 grid and place pieces of cheese on the tiles. When ready a virtual mouse will be set free and will scurry around the maze in search of the cheese. The mouse would run out of energy when searching for the cheese but remember the paths it had taken for future attempts and become more proficient. A later update changed the cheese to Martini glasses and made the mouse swagger the more it drank.
title: Mouse in the Maze

description: An early Chess game was developed on the MANIAC I computer in Los Alamos. Unlike earlier attempts at chess games this game did allow players to run a full game of chess, but it used a simplified board with only 6x6 squares. It implemented Claude Shannon's system for determining a move (as implemented in the Electric Chess Automaton in 1949). The game calculated all possible moves over two levels of the decision tree and then used static factors and minimaxing to determine the best move. The computer could do roughly 11,000 operations per second and calculating a turn took 12 minutes. It is known to have played three games. It's reported to have roughly equal skill to a player with twenty matches of experience.
title: Chess

description: The NSS Chess Program is an early chess game and the first system known to have won against a human opponent, albeit an amateur just introduced to the game. It elaborated on the design of The Berstein Program by adding "branch and bound' process which allowed the computer to consider fewer moves to determine its move.
title: The NSS Chess Program

description:
Spacewar! is a two player shooter where both players engage in a dog fight with space ships (called The Needle and The Wedge respectively). At the centre of the screen there is a star which pulls the ships constantly towards it. The space ships have limited fuel with which to manoeuvre, and a limited number of torpedoes which are used to destroy the opponent. The ships follow Newtonian physics and can use tactics such as a gravity assist. Players can also activate hyperspace which teleports the ship to a random other location, but with an ever increasing chance of self-destruction.

The game was initially controlled with switches, but a gamepad was later developed to make the game easier to play.

In initial versions the background stars were randomly generated. In later versions the game incorporated the Expensive Planetarium program which was based on real star charts.

sample_screenshots.caption: Needle vs. Wedge standoff
Got 'em!

title: Spacewar!

description: BBC Vik: The Baseball Demonstrator allows the player to "play" baseball against the computer and was created to demonstrate the IBM 1620 computer. Both the player and the computer pick players from a database to form a team and those teams will play against each other. The results of the matches are based on random numbers and batting averages from the database. Each event during the match is printed by the computer, letting the player know who hit the ball, when a base is stolen, a ball is caught, the pitcher hit the batter, etc. The only commands available to the player are cheats to force a hit or miss, or to request a postion of all the runners. A game lasted around 7 to 11 minutes.
title: BBC Vik: The Baseball Demonstrator

description: This 3D Tic-Tac-Toe conversion ran on the IBM 1620 and has a 3x4x4 grid and allows the player to play against the computer. Various versions of the game exist both written in FORTRAN and Assembly. The game was later reverse engineered and appeared on various other computer systems.
title: 3D Tic-Tac-Toe

description: Carmonette II is the successor to Carmonette. It expanded on its predecessor by including the modelling of infantry units in addition to the tank/anti-tank engagements. The game was used by the US military until replaced by its successor in 1966.
title: Carmonette II

description: The third entry in the Carmonette military training simulation series expands on its predecessors by adding armed helicopter support. It models combat scenarios for battalions and companies. Units can be ordered to move, stay still, prepare fire and fire.
title: Carmonette III

description: The last entry in the Carmonette military training simulation series expands on its predecessors by adding modelling of night vision and communications to the existing model of tank/anti-tank, infantry and armed helicopter support. It models combat scenarios for battalions and companies. Units can be ordered to move, stay still, prepare fire and fire.
title: Carmonette IV

description:
In Space Travel the player is free to explore the solar system. The game uses a two dimensional scale model of the solar system and the player is free to fly around. Physics are simplified as the player is only affected by the single strongest pull at a given time. There are no explicit objectives in the game, but the player can navigate around the solar system and attempt landings on planets and moons. The space craft can be moved and turned and the simulation speed can be increased to quickly reach destinations.

In order to port the game to the PDP-7 the developer created his own operation system which would later evolve to become Unix.
title: Space Travel

description:
Moonlander is the first graphical real-time version of Lunar Lander. It was commissioned by DEC to showcase the capabilities of the DEC GT40 graphics terminal.

The game showed a side-view of a mountainous lunar landscape in vector graphics. The lander would drop down and it was up to the player to make sure it would land on a flat surface without too much velocity. Using the light pen the direction and throttle of the thruster could be adjusted.
title: Moonlander

description: The Socratic System is an "intelligent tutor" game that teaches medical students how to diagnose patients. According to the author it's based on "logical conditions of sufficiency, necessity, redundancy, and consistency." In the game both the computer or player can take the initiative. The player has a vocabulary list of forty questions (about physical exam results and lab reports) and thirty-five declarative statements. The computer would follow up each question or statement with a response. The computer would use the gathered information to answer questions, reprove hasty conclusions, acknowledge perceptive decisions, question the grounds of inference, suggest new approaches, and develop contingencies.
title: The Socratic System

description: This Dice Game appeared in the Decuscope volume 3 (newsletter) and ran on a DEC PDP-5. All that is known about it aside of who made it, is that it required no additional hardware to run and that it simulated a game of dice (most probably Craps).
title: Dice Game

description:
The NASA Scene Generator was a training game for NASA employees. It featured multiple game modes that could be loaded:

  • A lunar landing simulation.
  • A spaceship docking simulation.
  • A shooting game in which the player controlled an airplane or helicopter and had to fire bullets at a moving tank.
  • An aircraft-carrier landing simulation.
  • An airport landing simulation.

The system used a color raster-scan display and made use of a joystick-like controller.
title: NASA Scene Generator

description: Pool Game is a two player game made for demonstration purposes to promote raster screen displays. A later version used vector displays. It was first shown at the Joint Computer Conference in San Francisco in the fall of 1966. Players compete against each other in a game of pool. The light pen is used to move the cue stick and hit the balls to try to pocket them; it's possible to apply sideways spin (english) to the balls. The game keeps score.
title: Pool Game

description:
This pool simulation was first displayed at the open house at David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, New Jersey on a RCA Spectra 70/25 computer with an IDI vector display.

The game features 15 numbered balls, and a dotted cue ball. Lines marked the boundaries of the table which balls would bounce against. The game featured no visual cue stick. When breaking the balls the speed of the balls would vary as the computer strained to keep up with the simulation.
title: Pool Game Simulation

description: T.E.M.P.E.R. (Technological Economic Military Political Evaluation Routine) is a military simulation game used by the United States Department of Defense/Joint Chiefs of Staff. It was the first world model of international conflict. The game was the first dynamic interdisciplinary mathematical model of long-term global Cold War conflict. Multiple countries and blocs are simulated in the game on an economic, military and political level. The computer makes decisions for a nation for all these models including interaction with other nations. The user can set an initial set of conditions and the model will generate a hypothetical history for a time span of roughly a decade. Ten to twenty nations could be simulated at a time.
title: T.E.M.P.E.R.

description:
Kalah is an adaptation of the board game with the same name, which is part of the Mancala family of games. The game is played by one player against an AI opponent. Each player has six round pits and a Kalah, which is a longer pit. When starting out three stones are evenly distributed to the round pits. The aim of the game is to collect more than half of the stones in the player's Kalah.

In each round the player takes all stones from one pit and distributes them anti clockwise around the board with one in each pit. If the last stone lands in the players' own Kalah, they must make one more move. If the last stone ends in a pit on the player's side and the pit on the other side is empty, all stones in that pit will be captured. The game stops if no more moves can be made by the players and the opponents then get to count their remaining stones to their total or when one player has more than half of the stones.

While the game can be played with two players, either or both can also be substituted by the computer. When a player is on turn the space bar can be pressed to let the computer make the move. The state of the game is displayed on a CRT or printed on a teletype printer. When the game finishes the computer declares which player won and what the final score was.
title: Kalah

description: The PDP-10 Timesharing World Series is one of the first games ever made for the BASIC programming language. The game allows the user to simulate a game of baseball on the computer. The player's input is limited to picking a random number between 1 and 1000 after which the game is played out. The two teams (Dodgers and Yankees) will bat it out. Based purely on chance the baseball players will hit singles, doubles or home runs, steal a base, be safe or out. Each event is printed to the screen and at the end a winner is announced.
title: The PDP-10 Timesharing World Series

description: Bingo is as the name implies a digital version of Bingo. The players receive a randomized printed bingo card for both themselves and the computer. The computer will then call numbers which the player can cross off the cards. The computer will tell when the player or computer has bingo or when the game ends in a tie.
title: Bingo

description:
Theaterspiel is a military training simulation game similar to Hutspiel. The primary difference is that it models an entire theater of war. It was used by the United States for studying Army problems with a focus on ground combat operations, but it also includes air operations, air defense and logistics. All the bookkeeping and most of the assessment procedures are handled by the computer. The player takes the role of the theater commander and must make all the decisions. Combat results are generally resolved on division level. Input for the game is handled with punch cards and the results are printed using a line printer. Each player is supplied with a status of all forces at the start of the game and a map and intelligence which differs between the two teams.

In each turn a team generates orders (movement, posture, designation, etc.) for its units. A third "control" team has to inspect the validity and feasibility of the orders and compares the orders with the other team's orders and determines the outcome of the combined orders. The computer then further processes that data and updates and prints the battlefield status. The game ends after a predetermined number of days or a specific event such as being overrun.
title: Theaterspiel

description: PDP 10 Timesharing Basketball is a turn-based textual basketball game written in BASIC. It places the player in the role of captain and playmaker of one team and plays against the computer. The player can give the following commands: Long jump shot, short jump shot, lay up and set shot. While defending the player can press, man-to-man, zone, none. The effects of each action is determined mostly by random chance.
title: PDP 10 Timesharing Basketball

description: Baseball is a BASIC game that plays out the 1967 world series between the Red Sox and Cardinals. All the players are present and probabilities for their actions can be requested when asked to make a move. The game itself is mostly played by answering yes or no questions, or a base to perform an action with. Questions include whether to steal a base, or which base to throw a ball to.
title: Baseball

description: Blackjack Game is a game created for demonstrative purposes of the IBM 1620 Data Processing System. It allows the player to play a game of blackjack. The main purpose of the game was to show off the randomization method.
title: Blackjack Game

description: In the IBM 1620 Blackjack Demonstration the computer is the dealer as the two players play blackjack. The players can choose to hit or fold and the computer will make these choices automatically for itself. Each card drawn is printed by the teletype printer. It is not possible to split hands.
title: 1620 Blackjack Demonstration

description: The 1620 Simulation of a One-Armed Bandit is exactly what it says. The player can spin the wheels by pressing the start key and the computer will show the results of each of three wheels. There are 6 characters which will be chosen randomly depending on predetermined odds. The player receives a pay-off based on the results which are printed by the computer. The player can choose between fifteen different amounts to bet, from five to ninety cents. Players can end their play at any time which enables a new player to start. The machine keeps track of the total winnings and losses of the entire day.
title: 1620 Simulation of a One-Armed Bandit

description: Three Dimensional Tick-Tack-Toe allows the player to play Qubic against the IBM 650 computer. Plays are made in turn by entering coordinates in a 4 by 4 cube with the objective of getting four in a row.
title: Three Dimensional Tick-Tack-Toe

description: The Checker Demonstration Program allows players to play Checkers against the computer. All the normal checker rules apply, moves are printed for both the player and computer. The computer can be made to punch out a card of the current game state which can be loaded up at a later time to continue play.
title: Checker Demonstration Program

description: A Chess Playing Program for the IBM 7090 Computer, also known as the Kotok-McCarthy-Program after its creators, is a chess game that is credited to be the first that would play a convincing game. It was being worked on at MIT between 1959 and 1962 and is based on the 1957 Bernstein program, but with added routines for alpha-beta pruning. It was later further developed at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at Stanford and lost an epic 9 month match against a Russian M-2 computer in 1966 by 3-1 despite running on faster hardware.
title: A Chess Playing Program for the IBM 7090 Computer

description: The ITEP Chess Program is a Soviet Chess simulator run on M-2 and M-20 computers. It uses a Shannon Type A algorithm to determine its moves. In 1966 it won against the American Kotok-McCarthy-Program with a 3-1 score in a match that lasted 9 months.
title: ITEP Chess Program

alternate_titles.description: Entry name in the in the monthly Boylston Chess Club Tournament at the Young Mens Christian Union
alternate_titles.title: Robert Q

description: Mac Hack VI, a.k.a. The Greenblatt Chess Program is a chess program that ran on the PDP-6. It was written in MIDAS and was the first computer program to play in a human tournament and be granted a chess rating in 1967. The game was inspired by the Kotok-McCarthy-Program, but improved upon it in design and search width.
title: Mac Hack VI

description: Mill is an implementation of the board game Nine Men's Morris for the PDP-1.
title: Mill

description: In the PDP-7/9 Dice Playing Program the players can place bets in an attempt to increase their amount of virtual dollars. The player wins if he/she can earn more than 9999 dollars. After each bet two dice are rolled. The sum of the two dice must be rolled again on a successive roll to get a payout, but once a seven is rolled the player loses the bet. If the initial roll is a seven or an eleven the player immediately wins. If it's a two the player immediately loses.
title: PDP-7/9 Dice Playing Program

description:
101 BASIC Computer Games is a compilation of BASIC games and applications released by DEC. It was later re-released independently in a slightly different format. A portion of the games were ported from DEC's FOCAL language to BASIC.

It includes the following games:

  • Acey Ducey
  • Animal
  • Awari
  • Bagles
  • Baseball
  • Basketball
  • Battle of Numbers
  • Naval Ship Battle
  • Bingo
  • Blackjack
  • Blackjack (alternate version)
  • Boat
  • Bomber
  • The Alley
  • Olympic Boxing
  • Bug
  • Bulls and Cows
  • Bullseye
  • Bull
  • Can-Am
  • Checkers
  • Chief
  • Chomp
  • Civil War
  • Craps
  • Cube
  • Digits
  • Dog Race Game
  • Get Even and a cybernetic version
  • Flip-Flop Game
  • Football
  • N. F. U. Football
  • Furs
  • Golf
  • Gomoko
  • Guess
  • Gunner
  • Artillery Firing Range
  • Game of Hangman
  • Hello
  • Hexapawn
  • Hi-Lo
  • Hi-Q
  • Hamurabi
  • Cornell U. Hockey
  • Horse Race
  • Hurkle
  • Pollution Game
  • Letter: A Letter Guessing Game
  • Life
  • Life II
  • Lit Qz
  • Mathdice
  • Matilda's Monopoly for Two
  • Mugwump
  • Boomerang Puzzle
  • Nim
  • Number Game
  • Solitaire Checker Puzzle
  • Orbit
  • Pizza
  • Poker
  • Qubic
  • Queen
  • Reverse
  • Lunar, Rocket, and LEM
  • Rocks, Paper, and Scissors
  • Roulette
  • Russian Roulette
  • Salvo
  • Salvo1
  • Slots
  • Spacewar (Star Trek)
  • Splat
  • Stars
  • Stock: Stock Market Simulation
  • Synonym
  • Target
  • Tic-Tac-Toe
  • Towers of Hanoi Puzzle
  • Trap
  • Game of 23 Matches
  • War (card game)
  • War
  • Word
  • Yahtzee
title: 101 BASIC Computer Games

description: Artillery is a textual game in which two or three players must try to hit each other with a piece of artillery. Unlike later artillery games there is no concept of terrain, wind, or varying firing velocity. A player must say which opponent to fire at and try to find the correct angle to hit him. The game is played in turns and the first player to fire within 5% error margin of the distance wins.
title: Artillery

description:
Doomsday 2000 is a rogue-like game with a science fiction setting. An alien race called the Zytts have invaded planet Earth. The player is on a mission to recover an anti-matter bomb in a military installation in the Appalachian Mountains.

Levels are randomly generated into 16 different regions per mission, side levels (warrens) and detention levels. The rarity of items is also random making a certain type of item rare in one game but common in another. Aside from weapons the player will find many other items which can be used to interact with the environment. Instead of "magic items" the game has strange devices. To find out what a strange device does the player must identify it at a library or find out through trial and error.

Initially the Mainframe game featured only a single mission, this was later expanded to three.
title: Doomsday 2000

description: The original version of Tetris was programmed on a Electronika 60 at the the Soviet Academy of Sciences at Computer Center in Moscow. In this puzzle game the player must direct randomly spawned Tetromino blocks (in seven different shapes) down the screen in an attempt to fill lines. Blocks can be rotated and translated in the horizontal axis, they automatically drop down and will fall faster the further the game progresses. Blocks stack untop of each other and if a block no longer fits at the top of the screen the game is over. A full horizontal line is removed making everything above it fall down and thus freeing up space to continue play.
title: Tetris

description: The Technology Chess Program is a chess program using a Shannon Type A Strategy developed at Carnegie Mellon University. The game competed three times at the ACM North American Computer Chess Championship and was a runner up in 1971 and 1972. It was one of the first chess programs to use brute force instead of evaluating a small subset of moves.
title: The Technology Chess Program

description: Kaissa is a Soviet chess program named after the Renaissance chess goddess Caïssa and developed at the Moscow Institute of Control Sciences. It won the 1974 World Computer Chess Championship in Stockholm and became second and forth in 1977 and 1980 respectively. The program uses a Shannon Type A strategy.
title: Kaissa

description: Apawam is a golf game which allows the player to play on the Apawamis Country Club. The player can use a wood, iron, putter and wedge club. With values the player determines the strength of the swing. From the tee the player is told the distance to the hole and after each swing the new distance is made known. In the green the player can use the putter. The ball can also be in the rough. At the end of the 9 holes the players can compare their scores to the par of 36.
title: Apawam

description: Digits is a number guessing game. The player is asked to write down three lines of 10 digits, where each digit can be 0, 1 or 2. The computer will then try to guess your numbers. The player must input the number sets and the computer compares it with its guesses. If it guessed correctly more than 10 times the computer wins, otherwise the player wins or it's a tie when exactly 10 guesses were correct.
title: Digits

description: ATC is a text-mode Air Traffic Controller game. Aircraft appear periodically and must be directed to the correct exit gate according to their flight plan. Aircraft can be given direct commands (e.g. turn left), relative commands (e.g. turn towards exit #2), or delayed commands (e.g. at beacon #1, turn left), as well as commands to adjust altitude. As the game progresses, more planes will enter the control area at a time. The game does not end; the goal is simply to direct as many planes as possible to their desired exit. As soon as a mistake is made, the game ends.
title: atc

description:
Arithmetic is an arithmetic quiz application. The game will ask a sequence of arithmetic questions, and will continue with each correct answer. If an answer is entered incorrectly, the game will remain on that question until the correct answer is entered. After each 20 questions, the game will report your score so far.

The game will initially only ask addition and subtraction questions, but multiplication and division questions can be enabled by using command-line parameters.

sample_screenshots.caption: The summary page is displayed after 20 responses. Unlike the later version, this version pauses for a few seconds before prompting to continue.
Running with multiplication and division enabled. A sample wrong answer is provided.
The earlier 2.11 BSD version of arithmetic running on SIMH. Answering a few basic questions correctly.

title: Arithmetic

description:
This is a terminal implementation of the classic board game, Backgammon. Per the original, each player must roll two dice, then use the resulting values to move the pieces forward on the board. The objective is to move all your pieces off the board, while preventing your opponent from doing the same. Two pieces on the same position will block your opponent from moving into that slot. Landing on a position with only piece will send it back to the beginning.

All moves in this version of the game are entered as comma-separated commands and can be either entered as position to position (10-12,4-8) or as start position/value (12/2,4/4).

This version of the game also contains a tutorial with the command 'teachgammon', which explains the rules of the game, then starts a pre-rolled match for practice.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting the tutorial (aka teachgammon)
Playing a game
Instructions

title: Backgammon

description:
Battlestar is an early text adventure game, described as a 'stellar-tropical adventure game' in the source code header. You initially find yourself in in a battlestar that is under attack and must make your escape. However, there are many useful items in the battlestar that you may need before you escape, but only so many turns before it explodes.

Battlestar is interesting among text adventures in that it tracks the current player orientation and updates the directions based on the current facing. For example, entering the room on the 'right', would result in a direction of 'behind' for leaving the room again. Re-entering the room would then be 'behind' when back in the corridor. Absolute directions (N,S,E,W) are possible, but only when a compass is found.

Battlestar was originally written for the PDP-11/70. It was eventually included as part of BSD, which was subsequently ported to Linux.

sample_screenshots.caption: Dead bodies in the dining hall. Cylons, huh? You don't say.
In space you can encounter enemy craft which will start a rather poor space combat minigame
A rather bumpy landing on the planet's surface. Some mistakes will penalize you with injuries, which then reduce your carry capacity
Starting the game
Taking the Viper out to escape our doomed battlestar.

title: battlestar

description:
Boggle is a text-mode reimplementation of the board game Boggle. Per the original, a random selection of letters appears on a 4-by-4 grid, and the objective is to identify as many complete words as possible. Subsequent letters must be adjacent either horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

After the round is complete, the game will list all available words on the board, and provide a percentage rating based on how many you located. Using the Esc key then typing any listed word will highlight it on the board to clarify what was missed.
title: Boggle

description:
BJ is an early terminal implementation of Blackjack. Each hand is printed in shorthand (e.g. JC for Jack of Clubs), with the user being prompted to hit. If yes is answered, an additional card is drawn. If no, the player stays, the dealer performs their play, and the round is over.

Per standard rules of Blackjack, the objective is to reach a card value of 21 without going over. Most cards have their numerical value, Jack/Queen/King have a value of 10, and Ace has a value of either 11 or 1.

sample_screenshots.caption: I hit to get to 19, but the dealer ends up at 20 and I lose. My next deal is a pair of tens, and I'm given the option to split.
I choose not to split and win with the 20 points. The next game starts me with a 5 and 8.
Starting a game with the 4 of spades and 8 of diamonds
I take a rather risky double-hit and end up with 21 points.

title: Bj

description:
Boggle is a text-mode reimplementation of the board game boggle. Per the original, a random selection of letters appears on a 4-by-4 grid, and the objective is to identify as many complete words as possible. Subsequent letters must be adjacent either horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

There is no visible timer in this version of Boggle; the passage of time is instead indicated by terminal bell sounds. If the terminal sound is turned off, this can result in the game ending rather suddenly. After the round is complete, the game will list all available words on the board compared to those you located, and indicate which provided words are errors.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting a fresh game. I don't know what I was thinking with 'neer'.
Ending the second game early with Ctrl + C. The computer shamed me with my selection of 'neer'.
The first game board. Entering a couple word choices
Starting the game and displaying the help text, which does not completely fit on the screen.
At the end of the game. Note that I accidentally typed 'h' as the answer to the another game prompt, as I was still typing when the game ended.

title: Boggle

description:
This is a terminal implementation of the classic board game, Backgammon. Per the original, each player must roll two dice, then use the resulting values to move the pieces forward on the board. The objective is to move all your pieces off the board, while preventing your opponent from doing the same. Two pieces on the same position will block your opponent from moving into that slot. Landing on a position with only piece will send it back to the beginning.

All moves in this version of the game are entered as a sequence of piece positions to move, in the same order as the dice role is listed. For example, with a dice role of 6 and 5, an entry of ‘12 4’ would move the piece on position 12 forward by 6, and the piece on position 4 forward by 5.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting the game with a double 2 roll, so I get to move four times
A couple rolls later in the game
I moved two pieces each from positions 19 and 1. Next role is a 6 and 1
Instructions

title: Btlgammon

description:
Canfield is a terminal implementation of Canfield solitaire. Per the original, cards are organized into four locations. In this version, they are labelled as foundation, tableau, stock and talon. The objective is to move all cards into the foundation. Cards in the foundation start at a given rank (e.g. 7) and that must match the first card placed in each position. Cards must then match suite and increase by rank (e.g. 8 on top of 7), wrapping around if needed.

The tableau is the work area, where cards can be stacked and shifted as needed to expose cards for play. Here, cards decrease in rank, using alternating colours (e.g. red 9 on black 10). The stock is a stack of cards, of which only the top card can be played at any given time. The remaining cards in the stock are inaccessible until exposed. Finally, the talon is the currently active card, and can be cycled through based on the hand in play. Like other solitaire games, the talon is cycled three cards at a time, though only one is visible in this version of the game.

This game can also follow casino betting rules, which charges for hands cycled, initial inspection and a few other things, while crediting cards placed. This information can be ignored if just playing the game for fun, however.

sample_screenshots.caption: Instructions screen
Playing quite a few more cards. Note that the foundation has wrapped from Queen to King, Ace then 2.
Adding a couple cards to the foundation and tableau
Starting a game with a foundation rank of Queen

title: Canfield

description:
Cribbage is a terminal implementation of the classic card game. The objective is to reach the end of the board and optionally return to the start before your opponent. You may advance along the board depending on score earned both while playing cards in sequence with your opponent, or based on the value of the resulting four card hand after a full play. When playing in sequence, the total value of cards played must remain below or equal to 31. The last player capable of playing is able to ‘go’, and the sequence repeats until all cards are played.

The following items are worth points during play: Reaching a value of 31 points: 2 points A ‘GO’ when the opponent is unable to play: 1 point A total value of 15: 2 points A sequence of three cards: 2 points A pair of cards: 2 points Flush (e.g. all cards in hand of same suit): 2 points Jack of the same suite as the starter: 1 point

This version of cribbage, although it performs automatic counting during play, requires the player to manually compute the value of their hand after play. Errors in score entry are reported by the computer accordingly. If using the -e command-line argument, a more detailed explanation of the score error is provided.

sample_screenshots.caption: Playing the first hand. The current total has reached 24 points, but I am unable to get to 31 points from here.
Starting a game. I am asked to discard two cards to make a hand of four
Reaching 30 points; I am unable to place more cards, so the computer is told to 'GO'
Selecting the discard points for the second hand. The computer has a 3 point lead on me.

title: Cribbage

description:
Fish is the classic card game of ‘Go Fish’. In this game, each player has a set of cards, and the objective is to empty your hand while collecting more ‘books’ of four cards with matching face values than your opponent. Each play, you must ask your opponent if they have the same card as one in your hand. If yes, they must give you all of those cards that they own. If not, you must ‘go fish’ to find the card in the ‘pool’ of cards that are not in either hand, and then add it to yours.

This is a simple terminal implementation of the game, where you enter the number or letter of the card to ask for. The computer has two difficulty settings; the harder setting is requested by pressing the ‘p’ key.

sample_screenshots.caption: A few guessing exchanges
Later in the game. The hand is getting a bit unwieldy, but both of us finally formed a book
Instructions and my first hand

title: Fish

description:
Gomoku is a terminal implementation of a classic match-5 game played on a 19x19 Go board. Players take turns to place pieces one at a time on the board. Similar to tic-tac-toe or ‘connect-4’, the objective is to make a unbroken line of five pieces, either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally anywhere on the board.

Moves are entered by typing the desired coordinate for the piece. The game can be played against the computer, against another player, or by pitting the computer against itself.
title: Gomoku

description: This is a terminal implementation of the classic game of hangman, typically played using a pen and paper. A series of unknown letter positions are marked with underscores, and a gallows is drawn. The player must then sequentially guess the letters that make up the unknown word. On each mistake, a body part of a hanged man is drawn on the gallows. If the full man is drawn (7 mistakes in this version), the player loses. If the player guesses all letters in the word, they succeed.

sample_screenshots.caption: And I guessed it!
Starting a game with an empty gallows
Guessing a few letters. Two body parts are added to the hanged man for my failures
Making some more progress

title: Hangman

description:
Hunt is a multi-player networked deathmatch game where each player is spawned in a random position in a maze. The objective is to find your opponents and kill them.

The game uses a text mode interface using the VI control keys. It tracks the facing of your character and line-of-sight, so it is possible to sneak up on enemies and backstab them.

Weapons are handled by a series of keys that shoot either bullets, or various sizes of explosives, mines and slime weapons. It is also possible to operate a scanner to locate enemies, or enable a cloak which will obscure you from scanners. All of the above take charges from a universal ammo pool. Additional ammo can be found scattered throughout the maze.

The game supports both free-for-all and team play, with up to 10 unique teams.
title: Hunt

description:
Mille is a terminal re-implementation of the Parker Brothers Mille Bornes card game. The objective is to be the first to reach a distance of 700 miles, which can be optionally extended to 1000 miles by the first player to reach it. Each turn consists of pulling a single card from the deck, followed by either playing or discarding a card. Distance is accrued by playing cards corresponding to the distance to travel. Other cards consist of hazards/conditions (e.g. flat tire), counters to the hazards (e.g. spare tire), and rare protections against hazards (e.g. puncture proof). The game starts with the ‘Stop’ condition active, and a ‘Go’ card must be played before you may move.

This particular version of the game is played solo against the computer.

sample_screenshots.caption: I managed to end the speed limit, only to run out of gas.
High value distances are starting to stack up in my hand, but I'm still blocked by the speed limit. I've given the CPU a flat tire.
Both of us have started the race and traveled 100 miles. The CPU has inflicted a speed limit on me, blocking the 75 and 100 mile cards.
Starting the game

title: Mille

description:
Monop is a terminal implementation of the Monopoly board game. Players take turns to move along the board and purchase property. After all properties in a set have been acquired by a player, they may then develop houses and hotels on any of those locations. Other players that land on an owned location must pay rent to the owning player, based on the land value of the location and the development on it. The objective is to obtain a Monopoly on all property in play, while bankrupting your opponents.

This version must be played with human players, using commands to dictate actions to take on a given turn. For example, ‘print’ will display the current state of the board, while ‘trade’ will start a trade of properties/cards/money with another player.
title: Monop

description: Moo is a simple terminal implementation of the guessing game known as ‘Bulls and Cows’, which is itself similar (but earlier) than the board game Mastermind. A random assortment of 4 digits is selected by the computer and must be guessed. A successful guess in the correct position is referred to as a ‘Bull’, while a successful guess in the wrong position is referred to as a ‘Cow’. Guessing all numbers in the correct position (four Bulls) wins the round.

sample_screenshots.caption: Making more deductions. I have now confirmed that 1, 3, 7, and 9 are the selected numbers, but not in that order. However, I already have enough clues to guess the order next.
Starting a game with the obvious starting sequences. Backspace doesn't work, so I needed to re-do my second guess.
And complete!
Continuing to guess. I have isolated that neither 5 nor 6 is used, so I can use that pair to isolate other pairs.

title: Moo

description:
Phantasia is an early MUD for a variety of Unix systems with a distinct Lord of the Rings theme. Each player creates a character by selecting a class, and starts in a random location somewhat close to the coordinates of 0,0. Players may then explore, fight monsters, fight each other, gain experience and collect treasure throughout the land.

There are several general goals in the game. Collecting a crown between levels 10 and 1000 allows a player to be crowned King, and lord over or collect taxes from other players. Players reaching level 3000 become members of the Council of the Wise and may then teleport, cause interventions on other players, and search for the Holy Grail. Finding the Grail advances the player to the position of Valar, which grants them further options.

sample_screenshots.caption: Generating a character
Fighting an Imp
Starting the game
Starting out in Gondor
Checking the player list

title: Phantasia

description:
Quiz is a simple terminal quiz game. It can ask questions with a variety of topics using a series of simple text files. Each topic contains two or more matching categories and questions can be asked using any combination. For example, the ‘symbol number weight element’ can be used to specify the element name for the element’s symbol, or can be used to specify the element symbol given its number, or so forth.

At the end of a quiz (either from quitting or exhausting all questions) you are granted a score based on your success rate.

Although most topics consist of knowledge, there are several that take the form of math problems, such as arithmetic/answer, multiplication/answer, easy-sequence/next/name and hard-sequence/next/name. There are also quizzes to test knowledge of Morse code or Latin, and even Locomotive designations.

sample_screenshots.caption: Summary of results on the second element quiz
Starting a new quiz: I must name the element for a given symbol
Running the reverse quiz; I must provide the symbol for a given element name.
Quiz will list the available topics if none is chosen on the command-line
If you enter a blank answer, quiz will report the correct one. My Chemistry is rather rusty.

title: Quiz

description:
Sail is a multiplayer terminal naval combat game, initially based on the Fighting Sail board game. The objective is to destroy or capture all enemy ships among a variety of scenarios. Scenarios are divided between historic naval battles (e.g. ‘The Battle of Lake Erie’), fictional battles (‘Hornblower and the battle of Rosas bay’), and some slightly absurd ones (‘Curse of the Flying Dutchman’ and ‘Star Trek’).

The game plays in a pseudo turn-based fashion: commands are entered for a turn, then synchronized among all other players. Commands are entered as a sequence of numbers and letters. For example, ‘3r’ would result in moving forward three spaces, then turning right once. The turn will automatically time out and advance after a short delay, so there is not much time for strategizing. The game attempts to account for the effects of wind, ship orientation when receiving a broadside, damage and repairs, and differences in ship/crew capabilities. Like any good naval combat game, it also allows boarding parties.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting up the 'Star Trek' scenario. Who knew the Enterprise had 450 guns and used round shot?
Starting the game. My ship (a) is facing to the northeast, while the British ship (b) is facing directly towards me (northwest).
Selecting a scenario
Picking my ship (the Wasp) and initial loadout.
Maneuvering around in the Star Trek scenario.

title: Sail

description:
Robots is a classic terminal game. The objective is to escape a swarm of robots by forcing the robots to crash into each other. As you take a step, the robots will all move one step closer to you. If the robots collide with each other, they create a pile of wreckage, which can also be used to destroy other robots. Once you reach the edge of the board and are about to be eaten, you can also use a teleport move to appear at a different random position on the board and resume the escape attempt.

This entry is for the BSD clone of the original Robots game posted on Usenet. This version is more friendly to players, as it will prevent the player from accidentally moving into a square where they will be eaten by a robot. It also uses a smaller playing field than the original, using space on the right side of the screen to provide a control reference and score.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting the game
Cornered by the robots. Time to teleport!
About to crash the last robot
Cornered again. I've caused a couple robots to crash now
Starting on the second stage

title: robots

description: Snake is a simple terminal game where you need to escape from a hungry, man-eating snake. The exit is marked with a # and can be entered at any time. However, the goal is to collect as much money as possible before exiting, but without being eaten.

sample_screenshots.caption: I've collecting $50 and the snake is getting a bit close
Taking my winnings and leaving with a score of $50.
I started over and collected $300, but the snake ate me
Starting the game. Note that on some terminals, the I for the player appears misaligned from the terminal cursor.

title: Snake

description: Nim is a simple text-based adaptation of the ancient game in BASIC for the PDP-10. It does not feature any settings and the player plays against the computer with three piles of sticks of quantities 15, 14 and 13. Players take turns taking sticks from one of the piles. Whoever takes the last stick wins.
title: Nim

description: Time-Sharing Tic-Tac-Toe is a simple Tic-Tac-Toe game played against the computer. The human player chooses whether to go first or not and selects one of 9 fields to place their mark in. Whoever manages to get three marks in any direction in a row wins.
title: Time-Sharing Tic-Tac-Toe

description: Tromp is a clone of Tetris for the 1989 Obfuscated C Code contest. Like most versions of the game, the objective is to orient falling blocks of four squares so that they form an unbroken horizontal line in the playfield. When a line is formed, that row is removed from the board. If the board is filled to the top, the game is over. The objective is to survive as long as possible and earn a high score.

sample_screenshots.caption: Making some compromises
Finally got the line piece for the right side, but I've ended up with a bunch of holes
Building taller. I'm not getting very many L, J or line pieces
Starting a game
A few pieces later

title: Tromp

description: Warp is a Star Trek-themed terminal action game. You can control either the Enterprise or a nearby Starbase and switch between them at will. The objective is to destroy all enemies in a given wave. Enemies are taken from collection of Star Trek enemies (e.g. Klingons/Romulans) as well as some higher profile unique characters (Apollo, the Planet Crusher, etc.). The game contains a variety of actions, including phases/turbo lasers, attractor/repulsor beams, photon torpedos, cloaking devices, and the ability to switch between impulse and warp engines. The game ends when both the Enterprise and the Starbase are destroyed.

sample_screenshots.caption: Starting a game. There is one Klingon (K) on the map, with both the Enterprise (E) and Starbase (B) available for player control
The Enterprise is somewhat fruitlessly chasing the Klingon ship. I fired one torpedo, which got left behind fairly quickly.
Starting a different scenario.
Reading the manual

title: Warp

description: Hangman is a word-guessing game. The player must try to guess the word that the computer randomly chose, letter by letter. On each incorrect letter the player can opt to draw a picture of the current state. Unlike traditional hangman where the character is slowly built up until hanged, here the character slowly disappears until completely gone. The goal is to guess the full word before it comes to that.
title: Hangman

description: Bridge offers a practice session for the player. The game allows the player to bid on a given situation and will ask the player questions about the situation, when incorrect the player is told the correct answer or hints on what to do.
title: Bridge

description:
Baseball is an early baseball simulation game written on a PDP-10. The game was expanded on during the 1970s and was ported to the Apple II by the author in the early 1980s but never released. The game formed the basis of World Series Major League Baseball for the Intellivision. The game was later released also for the IBM 360/40 on punch cards.

In the game players pick their roster of existing players to play a single game with.
title: Baseball

description: Ecala is an enhanced update of the chatterbot Eliza for the PDP-10 minicomputer. The user can talk to the computer whose inquisitive nature will try to pry the user to reveal more and more.
title: Ecala

description: Mr. Turk is a chess program for the CDC 6600 developed at the University of Minesota in FORTRAN. Development started in 1967 and continued to at least 1971 when it participated in the ACM's Second North American Computer-Chess Championship. The game did not use alpha-beta routines and was worked on by multiple chess playing programmers.
title: Mr. Turk

description:
Reflect is an education game that teaches about the laws of light reflection.

The player is on a mountain in a national park when calamity strikes and must get help at a nearby bar on his old horse Lightray. The horse must be watered on the way and knowing the locations of the starting point, the river and the bar, the player must give the coordinate at which to drink to ensure the shortest travel distance.
title: Reflect

description:
Huntington Computer Project: A Teacher's Manual was a manual for teaching students to program in BASIC. Aside from teaching them how to create games the book also contained some games and game-like educational programs for the PDP-10 minicomputer.

Included games:

  • Reflect
  • The New Clea Casino
title: Huntington Computer Project: A Teacher's Manual

description: Worm is a simple terminal snake game. The objective is to eat a series of numbers that appear in the playfield and survive as long as possible. Each number will increase both your score and your snake length by the same amount. If you collide with the play area boundaries or yourself, you lose.

sample_screenshots.caption: The worm has grown a bit. Heading towards #8 now
Game over with a score of 57.
Starting out and heading towards the number 4
Living a bit dangerously

title: Worm

description:
Ttt is a terminal implementation of Tic-Tac-Toe. The player alternates with the computer by entering a number to place an X in corresponding to a square of interest, followed by a matching move for O by the computer. The objective is to place three Xes in a row either horizontally, vertically or diagonally.

This version of the game has an AI that learns from its mistakes. On a fresh system, the AI will play very poorly and lose most games. Given enough time, however, the AI will eventually play a perfect game. The learned information is saved to disk and can be re-loaded in later sessions.

sample_screenshots.caption: The computer has learned enough to cause a draw
Starting a game
Winning easily

title: ttt

description:
Life is the earliest implementation of Conway's Game of Life on a computer. The player can draw patterns and watch how they evolve based on the simple rules of Conway's Game of Life.

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.
title: Life

description: Darwin is an early programming game in which two or more users must try to conquer the arena (a segment of the computer's memory). The rules are governed by a program called the umpire which determines which functions can be called. Programs can probe memory locations, kill opposing programs and copy themselves to empty memory locations. The game ends after a set amount of time or when only one program (and its copies) remains alive. A limited number of memory allocations in a program can be set up as protected. When probing a protected memory allocation, the probed program would become active (until that program again hit a protected memory allocation).
title: Darwin

description: Qubic5 is an BASIC implementation of the board game Qubic. It's a game of tic-tac-toe on a 4x4x4 grid. The player and computer take turns placing an X or O and try to get 4 in a row.
title: Qubic5

description: Zer0s is a simple strategy puzzle game that's played against the computer and shares similarities with Nim. The playing field consists of 8 zeroes in a row. The spaces between them are numbered one through seven. The player and computer take turns picking a number and drawing a bridge. Adjacent bridges can't be drawn any more. When a player runs out of options that player has lost.
title: Zer0s

description: Lost in the Caves is simple text-based cave exploration game. The player is inside a cave with various passages and must try to find the exit by trial and error. There are multiple difficulties for different cave sizes.
title: Lost in the Caves

description: Beyond Bagels is a code breaking game inspired by Bagels. The player must guess a three-digit code. For each guess the player is scored, 1 point for a correct digit, and 1 additional point for a digit in the correct location.
title: Beyond Bagels

description: Caves2 is identical to Lost in the Caves with the exception that before starting to escape the player can create a custom cave and have another player try to escape.
title: Caves2

description: Caves3 is similar to Caves2 except that caves can loop back to previous caverns allowing for more complex mazes.
title: Caves3

description: The Killer Shrews is a simulation game inspired by the cult sci-fi film of the same name. The player manages population on an island with a dwindling food supply. The game was a stepping stone towards the seminal Utopia.
title: The Killer Shrews

description: This Go-playing program is the earliest known working implementation of Go on a computer. It was written as part of a thesis on pattern recognition and has roughly the skill of a beginning player.
title: Go

description: Dungeon is an unofficial adaptation of the table top RPG game Dungeons & Dragons for the PDP-10. The game is played mostly in text, but features a top-down view of the action in which only the areas that the player's party of characters can see (using line of sight, and individual abilities such as infravision to determine what should be visible). In encounters within the dungeon the player can determine what each character does. Aside from having a base class, race and statistics, characters earn experience points and grow in level.
title: Dungeon

alternate_titles.title: P.C.C.'s First Book of Computer Games

description:
What to Do After You Hit Return is a book that compiles type-in games and some non-game entertainment programs. The games are all written in HP 2000F Time Share BASIC. Most games previously appeared in issues of The People's Computer Company newsletter. Not all games described in the book have their source code included. The book includes instructions for ordering the games on magnetic or paper tape.

Included games:

  • Number
  • Abase
  • Trap
  • Stars
  • Clocks
  • Bagels
  • Quadgt
  • Button
  • Letter
  • Abagel
  • Hangman
  • Madlib
  • Word
  • 23Match
  • Batnum
  • Nim
  • Chomp
  • Zot
  • Hurkle
  • Mugwump
  • Snark
  • Life
  • Qubic5
  • Gomoku
  • Teaser
  • Rover
  • Caves1
  • Wumpus
  • Caves2
  • Hamurabi
  • King
  • Civil2
  • Market
  • Stock
  • Policy
  • Polut
  • Star Trader
  • Sttr1
  • Crash
  • Lunar
  • Reverse
  • Zeros
  • Taxman
title: What to Do After You Hit Return

description:
Nuclear Destruction is a computer moderated play-by-mail game. Players send in their commands for each turn by post and a single computer prints out the results which are sent back to all the players.

The goal of this strategic game is to be the sole survivor in a nuclear holocaust. Each player is in control of a nation and has a nuclear arsenal, money, factories, etc. Every two weeks the results of a turn are sent back during which players can decide on what to do. Missiles can be fired, alliances formed, messages sent, etc. Each player receives a score at the end of a game and every other month a player ranking list is publicized.
title: Nuclear Destruction

description:
Battle Plan is a computer moderated play-by-mail game. Players send in their commands for each turn by post and a single computer prints out the results which are sent back to all the players.

In this tactical war game each player plays a nation and the theatre of war is Europe. Each player can control resources such as armies, air forces, navies, missiles, anti-missiles, money, industry, spies, counterspies and research. The game is played with around 6-7 players and the goal is to conquer the whole of Europe. The game ends when there is only a single player left standing. Players without land, but who still have forces can continue playing.

Aside from moving forces around the map in order to conquer countries, players can undertake diplomacy with other players. Players have a sphere of influence which can put them in partial control of minor countries (countries not occupied by a player).

Research is used to improve forces, spies and counterspies, but money invested has a diminishing return. Money can also be spent on propaganda to increase or decrease the popularity of a player in a country, or alternative money can be kept unspent which yields interest.
title: Battle Plan

description:
Board of Directors is a computer moderated play-by-mail game. Players send in their commands for each turn by post and a single computer prints out the results which are sent back to all the players.

The game is an educational game in the vein of The Management Game. It puts the players (typically a classroom) in ten teams. Each team takes on the role of a corporation which manufactures a product. Players must decide on actions to take for the company, such as setting a price for the product, promotion, production and research. After each turn each group receives a financial statement showing how well the company is doing.
title: Board of Directors

description:
Starweb is a computer moderated play-by-mail game. Players send in their commands for each turn by post and a single computer prints out the results which are sent back to all the players. Turns generally last two weeks during which players have time to send their moves.

In this game 15 players compete over the conquest of 255 worlds. Each player starts with a single home world and must try to accumulate 10,000 victory points. Victory points are accumulated. Players choose between six different character types, and each type of character gains victory points in a different way:

  • The empire builder gains points for owning worlds, industry, mines and population.
  • The apostle gains points for converting population to his religion.
  • The pirate gets points for fleets and plundering worlds. He can capture enemy fleets.
  • The merchant gains points for transporting goods to their homeworld.
  • The artifact collector gains points for finding artifacts.
  • The berserker gains points for killing things and destroying planets.

Planets have various statistics, such as their population (and limit), resources, mines, industry, etc. The player can move fleets from planet to planet using star gates called "keys". Players have to explore these keys first before they can know where they lead.
title: Starweb

description: Abase is a number guessing game with an educational twist. Instead of picking a number using standard base 10 numbers, the player can pick a base and the computer will think of a number in that base. It's up to the player to guess it. After each guess the computer will tell the player if it was too high or too low. When the number is correctly guessed the player is told how many guesses it took.
title: Abase

description: ZOT is a tactical game in the vein of Nim for two players played on a grid of 4 by 5 stars. Each turn a player can remove stars in a row or column from the edge to a given star. Players decide up front if the person removing the last star wins or loses.
title: ZOT

description: Beal is a chess program written on a CDC 6600 Mainframe. It competed at the very first World Computer Chess Championship through a telephone line connection from Stockholm to London.
title: Beal

description: The Advanced Simulation in Undergraduate Pilot Training installation at Williams Air Force Base in Arizona was one of the first flight training simulators. It simulates a Cessna T-37. The installation linked two simulators on six degree-of-freedom hydraulic platforms to multiple computers (SEL Systems 86). It used seven displays around each user to simulate their view from the cockpit. On the displays polygonal graphics were displayed representing objects in their surroundings, scaled to distance. An additional instructor station allows additional input for the game on a console with a CRT screen.
title: Advanced Simulation in Undergraduate Pilot Training

description: Checkers allows the player to play the classic board game on the ILLIAC supercomputer. Standard checkers gameplay applies, where the player and the computer take turns moving their pieces diagonally on the game board. The computer AI learns from actions during the game but also tends to cheat because of a bug in the code.
title: Checkers

description: Uguess is a number guessing game for UNIX. The computer thinks of a number between 1 and 100 and it's up to the player to guess it.
title: Uguess

description: 10Guess is a number guessing game for UNIX. The computer thinks of a number between 1 and 10 and it's up to the player to guess it.
title: 10Guess

description: Mathdice is a children's dice rolling game for computers such as the EduSystem 30 and the UNIX operating system that involves addition of numbers represented by dice displayed on the screen (or printout).
title: Mathdice

description: 31 is an implementation of the classical card game for UNIX. Players take turns exchanging cards with the goal of getting a card value of 31 in any suit. The player who manages to get 31 or the highest value in a suit compared to other players wins the round.

Witchy the name witch has captured four friends of the player. The friends are held for ransom and it's up to the player to find them. The name of each friend is behind a fence, but each fence has one board missing, leaving one letter of the name visible. It's up to the player to guess which friend is behind which fence. Correct guesses release the friends, but incorrect guesses cause their names to be eaten. The witch's name is also in play and accidentally guessing that fence will cause the player's name to be eaten. Correctly guessing it causes the witch to eat her own name.
title: Witchy

description: Hang is a simple implementation of the classic pen and paper game Hangman. The player must guess a mystery word of a chosen length. After each guessed letter the locations of that later in the mystery word are shown, when guessing a letter that doesn't exist in the word part of a hanged man is drawn. If the hanged man is drawn fully the game is lost.
title: Hang

description: Alphabetsoup is a letter guessing game. The computer thinks of a letter and the player must guess it. After each guess the computer will give a hint which will narrow down the player's choices. Hints include whether it's a vowel or consonant, whether it has closed loops or legs.
title: Alphabetsoup

description: War is a single terminal two player game based on earlier Star Trek games, running on a CDC-6600 at the University of Texas. Players take turns at the keyboard in an effort to hunt each other down. Planets can be conquered to make them your own. The game was eventually rewritten and expanded on a DEC PDP-10 to become DECWAR.
title: War

description: DECWAR is an expanded and rewritten version of War for the DEC PDP-10. The game allows 10+ players playing with drop-in and drop-out functionality thanks to shared memory. The core gameplay is based on the game Star Trek, with players roaming around the galaxy picking fights between the Federation and Klingon Empire. In less populated games a computer controlled Romulan faction would also be in play. The game ends once a faction has destroyed all other faction's ships and conquered all planets.
title: DECWAR

description: Motie is an adaptation of the mathematical game, The Soldier's Game. The game can be played against the computer or another player. One player controls the Moties, an advanced race that will enslave humankind when they come into contact with them. The game board consists of interconnected interstellar jump points. The Moties have a ship which they can move one spot each turn; the humans have 3 ships they can move. The goal for the humans is to lock the Moties in so that they cannot make a valid move. The Moties win if they reach the human home world, aren't captured by turn 15 or if moves repeat for more than 3 times in a row.
title: Motie

description: Rescue puts the player in control of a rescue starship. The Starship Kiewit is in danger and the player must try to save the crew and passengers within a dozen moves. The game takes place on a 6x6 grid. Each turn the player can move the rescue ship one square. Moves can only be done in 4 directions, except in the centre of the grid, where diagonal movement is also allowed. The Kiewit will move automatically trying to avoid the rescue ship (after having it misidentified as a meteor). The goal is to move into the Kiewit's square within 12 moves.
title: Rescue

description:
Raumkrieg is a tactical space game. Each player controls 10 space ships of different types (flagships, battle cruisers and scout ships) with the goal of destroying each other's fleet. Moves of all players are sent in by (physical) mail and processed by the computers at Flying Buffalo, after which the results are mailed back to the players. Players can include messages to other players in their turn update, which will be included with the computer's simulation results.

The game space takes on a two dimensional arena from (0.0) to (999.999). Five to nine players per game set up their fleet in a designated region at the start of the game. Battle cruisers have a greater firing range than scouts and flagships can be used to capture enemy ships. Movement is done by allocating fuel to ships. Ships regain fuel each turn. Once a ship moves into a direction no further fuel is required to make it continue moving.

After movement ships fire. Anything in close range is automatically hit, but for short, medium and long range enemy ships need to be within specific angles to be hit. Each destroyed ship yields points, with the winner being whoever has most points at the end of turn 12.
title: Raumkrieg

description:
Moon Base places players on the moon in control of crawlers (which can deploy fixed, jumping and programmed mines), fixed guns, propelled guns, and command posts. The goal is to destroy the enemy command posts before they destroy yours. Moves of all players are sent in by (physical) mail and processed by the computers at Flying Buffalo, after which the results are mailed back to the players.

Each game takes a fixed number of turns during which players must score as many points as possible. Points are gained through the destruction of enemy units and lost by the destruction of your own. The game map consists of 133 hexagon tiles, which are subdivided into 16 areas of different terrain types (plain or crater). The layout of the land is different each game.

The player can use spy beams to reveal the layout of hex tiles, a beam can be used each turn and the player can have control over multiple beams.
title: Moon Base

description:
Time Trap is a tactical time travel game. Moves of all players are sent in by (physical) mail and processed by the computers at Flying Buffalo, after which the results are mailed back to the players.

The game allows for two to nine players. Each player has five assassins in a 16x16 array of squares. Each turn players can move any or all of their assassins one step in any direction (including diagonal). After movement the assassins can fire in any direction and up to one tile away. The real tactical aspect comes from an energy supply that is accumulated 10 points per turn by each player. Players can use it to change actions in turns that have already played out. The energy cost grows exponentially depending on how long ago the turn is that is changed.
title: Time Trap

description: STRTRK is a version of Star Trek written in BASIC for the HP 2000F. What distinguishes it from other versions of the game is that it allows for two terminals to play against each other. Each player controls a ship and can fly around the galaxy at warp speed, avoiding collisions with stars. Star bases can be used to refuel when they are owned by the player. Phasers can be used to fire at the other player.
title: STRTRK

description:
Ultimate Star Trek is a version of Star Trek that ran on the Santa Ana College computer. It was adapted heavily from the original to increase the challenge of the game.

Instead of moving the starship and firing torpedoes in directions of 45 degrees Ultimate Star Trek allows a direction in degrees. Additionally the Enterprise now has a cloaking device which makes it possible to sneak up to enemies. Probes can scan distant points of the galaxy without actually being close. To counteract this empowerment of the player more enemies are added, including the Romulans, Thallians, Eminians and Hortae. Each race has different statistics: The Romulans take simply more hits than Klingons to kill. Thalians make the enterprise immobile. Eminians have an anti-matter field which disables warp drives, phasers and photon torpedoes. The Hortae have a sonic disruptor beam which does extreme damage, but they are not naturally hostile to the player. The Thalians, Eminians and Hortae all don't show up on long distance scans.

When firing at a star with a torpedo the star will go into super nova and swallow up the entire quadrant.
title: Ultimate Star Trek

description: Battle is an implementation of the pen and paper game Battleship. The computer has set up its fleet of 6 ships of varying sizes randomly in a 6x6 grid and the player must destroy them by giving coordinates. The player receives a splash/hit ratio.
title: Battle

description: Baseball is a text-based baseball simulation written in BASIC. The player must decide on the actions of the pitcher or batter (depending on who's in play) in turn-based steps. Nine innings are played against the computer. Only a single game can be played.
title: Baseball

description: Blkjak is a text-based blackjack game. The player plays against the bank (computer) and must try to get 21 points with cards or as high as possible without going bust (over 21). Whoever has the highest amount wins the wager.
title: Blkjak

description: Boat places the player in a submarine. The goal is to destroy a gun boat controlled by the computer. Each turn the player can fire at the boat. The player must hit vulnerable parts of the boat twice, or once and two additional hits to win. Once the player misses the gun boat will fire back and try to destroy the player's submarine. After each hit a text-mode graphic of the gunboat is shown.
title: Boat

description: The Alley is a text-based bowling game. All the players have to do is type "roll" to roll the ball. The outcome is completely random. The game detects spares, strikes, and gutter balls.
title: The Alley

description: Olympic Boxing simulates a three-round Olympic boxing match in a text-only game. The player plays against the computer and must decide which punch to make. The player can choose between a jab, uppercut, full swing and hook. At the start of the match you must enter your advantage and vulnerability. For the opponent you will only learn his advantage, the vulnerability you need to find out through trial and error.
title: Olympic Boxing

description: Moo is an implementation of the pen and paper game Bulls and Cows (later commercially popularized as Mastermind). It ran on the Titan computer at Cambridge University. The player must guess a code of four numbers randomly picked by the computer. The player enters a code and receives an amount of bulls and cows in return. Bulls being numbers in the correct spot and cows being numbers in the code, but in a different spot. It's up to the player to deduce the code in the fewest possible steps.
title: Moo

description: Bradford University Bulls and Cows Game is an implementation of the pen and paper code-breaking game Bulls and Cows. The computer thinks of a code of five numbers and the players must try to guess it. After guessing the player is told his or her bulls (correct numbers in correct positions) and cows (correct numbers in incorrect positions).
title: Bradford University Bulls and Cows Game

description: Bull is a text-based bull fighting game. Each turn the bull's action is described and the player has the option between five different moves, three waves of the cape of various difficulties and two methods of going for the kill. The player will be rated on his bravery, posthumously if necessary.
title: Bull

description: Chief is a simple educational game teaching a mathematical operation with some humour. The computer takes on the role of a native American math god and gives a sum to the player. The player must try to solve it and will have it explained afterwards; giving strange answers to its questions will rile the math god.
title: Chief

description: Cube is a minefield traversal game. On a 2x2x2 grid five random mines are hidden. The player must try to go from one corner to the opposite without running into a mine.
