Before each run the player can make a wager on whether he or she will make it. The eventual goal is to earn as much money as possible.
title: Cube

description: Dog Race Game is a dog race betting game. Up to 19 players can play. Each player can bet on a dog. The previous wins and losses of each dog are shown up front to each player. Players may then bet on a single dog. The odds are then displayed and the dogs start running. The wins and losses are written to an external file and are persistent between play sessions.
title: Dog Race Game

description: Even Wins is a game in which the computer and player take turns picking a number of items from a limited odd-numbered stack. Each turn a participant can take between one and four objects. When all objects are gone, whoever has an even number wins. The computer uses an optimal strategy.
title: Even Wins

description:
Even Wins: Cybernetic Version is a game in which the computer and player take turns picking a number of items from a limited odd-numbered stack. Each turn a participant can take between one and four objects. When all objects are gone, whoever has an even number wins.

This implementation uses an AI that progressively learns how to play the game using data from previous games.
title: Even Wins: Cybernetic Version

description:
Football is a text-based football game in which the player makes choices for each play. The plays available depend on whether the player is on offensive or defensive:

Offensive plays:

  • Run
  • Pass
  • Sweep
  • Screen Pass
  • Long Pass
  • Draw Play
  • Punt
  • Fieldgoal

Defensive plays:

  • Normal
  • Hold
  • Blitz
  • Intercept
  • Block

The play made plus random odds will determine the outcome and the new game state. The player can only play against the computer.
title: Football

description:
N. F. U. Football (No FORTRAN Used) is a text-based football game for two players. Each turn both teams enter a play and the outcome of the combination is determined. The plays are numbered but the actual numbers are scrambled and printed for both players at the start so that on each new game a player doesn't know what the plays entered by their opponent mean. Plays include:

  • Pitchout
  • Triple Reverse
  • Draw
  • QB Sneak
  • End Around
  • Double Reverse
  • Left Sweep
  • Right Sweep
  • Off Tackle
  • Wishbone Option
  • Flare Pass
  • Screen Pass
  • Roll Out Option
  • Right Curl
  • Left Curl
  • Wishbone Option
  • Sideline Pass
  • Half-Back Option
  • Razzle Dazzle
  • Bomb!!!
title: N. F. U. Football

description: Gomoko is an adaptation of the board game Gomoku. The player and computer take turns to place markers on a grid. The goal is to get five in a row. This implementation allows board sizes from 7x7 to the traditional 19x19 to accommodate for various screen sizes. The computer does not keep track of who won the game.
title: Gomoko

description: Guess is a number guessing game. The player determines the upper limit. The computer thinks of a number and the player must guess it. The computer will signal if it's too high or too low.
title: Guess

description: Artillery Firing Range is a text-based artillery game. The player can decide on a target speed and blast radius. The target will move randomly. The player must give an elevation angle for his gun to try and destroy it.
title: Artillery Firing Range

description: Game of Hangman is a typical hangman game. The player must guess a word the computer has chosen letter by letter. For each incorrectly guessed letter a part of a hangman is drawn. Since the game is written with a teletype terminal in mind the player can choose whether to see the current drawing or not.
title: Game of Hangman

description: Hello is an entertainment-only chatbot, similar to Eliza. The bot will ask mostly closed questions in a fairly linear conversation.
title: Hello

description: Hi-Q is a peg solitaire game. Pegs are placed on a cross-shaped board and the player must try to remove all (except the last one) from the board by jumping over them. Each jumped peg is removed from the board.
title: Hi-Q

description: Cornell U. Hockey is a text-based hockey simulation in which the player plays against Cornell University. When the player is in control of the puck three options are available: slap shot, flick shot and wrist shot. The shots influence the game, which is otherwise mostly randomly determined, but features three periods, sudden death and a variety of situations such as penalties, blocked and wide shots and hitting the post.
title: Cornell U. Hockey

description: Lit Qz is a multiple choice children's literature quiz, it features questions about famous icons such as Pinocchio, Bugs Bunny, The Wizard of Oz and fairy tales.
title: Lit Qz

description: Matilda's Monopoly for Two is an unlicensed text-based implementation of the classic board game. Two players can play and take turns buying properties and paying rent to the other players when landing on theirs. All the rules are implemented and players can sell property to the other player. When one of the players goes bankrupt the other player wins. There are no visuals for the board.
title: Matilda's Monopoly for Two

description:
Boomerang Puzzle lets the computer guess a number the player is thinking of. The player will need to answer some questions, namely what the remainder is when dividing the number by 3, 5 and 7. The computer will always guess right and it's up to the player to figure out how the computer does it.

The puzzle first appeared in A.D. 90 in Arithmetica by Nicomachus.
title: Boomerang Puzzle

description: Number Game has the player guessing a number between 1 and 5. Depending on the proximity to the actual number the player earns points. Guessing the correct number wins the jackpot. The player starts with 100 points and wins once 500 points are reached.
title: Number Game

description: Poker allows the player to play heads-up poker against the computer. Both the player and computer start with $200. Each player is given five cards and after betting can get a number of cards replaced and another round of betting. Whoever has the best poker hand wins the bet. The game goes on until one of the players is bankrupt.
title: Poker

description: Rocks, Paper, and Scissors is a game that allows the player to play rock-paper-scissors against the computer. The computer picks randomly without any strategy.
title: Rocks, Paper, and Scissors

description: Salvo is a Battleship variant played on a 10x10 grid. The player plays against the computer. The number of shots per turn depends on the amount of ships the player still has in play. As in Battleship the goal is to destroy the entire enemy fleet before the player's is destroyed.
title: Salvo

description: Salvo1 is a Battleship variant. The player plays against the computer. Both hide four platoons on a separate 5x5 grid. The player and a computer take turns firing missiles trying to hit the enemy platoons. Whoever kills the enemy platoons first wins the game.
title: Salvo1

description: Splat is a parachute jumping game. The player will fall to the ground and must open the parachute at the last possible moment. The player can choose his own terminal velocity and gravity, or can let the computer decide. In the latter case the computer will pick one of the eight inner planets, the moon or the sun's characteristics. The computer will give a height and the player must respond how many seconds to wait until opening the parachute.
title: Splat

description: Synonym is a word guessing game. The computer will say a word and the player must guess synonyms of that word. The player can type "HELP" to get a synonym of the given word.
title: Synonym

description: Target is a target shooting exercise. The player is on the starship Enterprise and must shoot a target somewhere in 3D space. The player is given some information about the target: radians and degrees from the player's x and z axis, approximate coordinates and estimated distance. To fire the player gives an x angle, z deviation and distance. Afterwards the player will learn the amount of kilometres above, behind and to the side of the target the shot was. The player can then try again with improved estimates. There's no score tracking in the game, but a good player should be able to down a target within 3 to 4 shots.
title: Target

description: Towers of Hanoi Puzzle is a puzzle game in which discs of different sizes (up to 7) need to be moved from one tower location to another. There are three locations, but tower pieces can only be placed on larger pieces. Also only one piece can be moved at a time.
title: Towers of Hanoi Puzzle

description: In War the player and computer wage a war. The game is completely text-based. Each has up to 72,000 units which can be divided freely over army, navy and air force. The player may attack twice with one of the three forces and a given number of men. Depending on the results of those attacks the war will result in a treaty, total win or total loss.
title: War

description: Word is a word guessing game that borrows elements from Hangman and Mastermind. The player must guess a five letter word chosen by the computer. After each guess the player will be told which letters are in the mystery word and which are in the correct position. There is no limit to how often can be guessed.
title: Word

description: Yahtzee is an implementation of the classic dice game. The game allows play for up to fifteen players. All the usual rules apply. On a turn a player rolls five dice and can re-roll (a selection) twice. Scoring is divided in multiples of a value (amount of aces, twos, threes, etc.) and special rolls such as full house and Yahtzee (5 identical dice). After each turn the player must decide what to write, or strike out one of the available options if nothing matches. Getting at least 63 points with multiples will yield a bonus score of 35 points. Whoever scores the most points at the end wins.
title: Yahtzee

description: Core War is a two player programming game similar to Darwin. The goal is to copy a program into memory as much as possible while trying to break the opponent's program which is trying to do the same. It inspired a host of similarly named games over the decades to come.
title: Core War

description: Planets is a text-based puzzle game in which the player must try to navigate all the major bodies in the solar system in the shortest possible flight path. The player starts and ends at planet Earth and there are three difficulty levels.
title: Planets

description: Hats is a code cracking game. The computer has a secret code. The player can call out a number and the computer will give a response. If the player thinks he or she has understood the code the computer will test the player to see if the player gives the correct responses.
title: Hats

description: Vanishing Snake is a Hangman variant. The player must guess a word determined by the computer one letter at a time. After each guess the player either sees a letter appear on the right position, or part of a 12-part snake disappear. The player wins if all letters in the word are guessed and loses if the snake fully disappears.
title: Vanishing Snake

description:
Pack 1 is a compilation of educational games developed at the Community Computer Center. It features the following games and programs:

  • Number
  • Letter
  • Stars
  • Story: A program that knits a selection of nouns into a short story.
  • Snake
  • Cricket
title: Pack 1

description: Cricket is a puzzle game in which the player must find the location of a cricket that hides on a two dimensional grid. Each turn the player may move one space in any direction. The Cricket has a 50% chance of moving in a random direction. The player wins when ending up in the same space as the cricket.
title: Cricket

description:
The Best of Creative Computing: Volume 1 compiles work from the first six issues of Creative Computing. Included are some BASIC games listings:

  • Hunt the Wumpus
  • Depth Charge
  • Notone (No listing of the game is actually printed)
  • Civil War
  • Guess
  • Reverse
  • Schmoo
  • Seawar
  • Lunar Landing
  • Geowar
  • Splat Parachute Jump
  • ICBM
  • Rabbit Chase
  • Magic Square
  • Super Star Trek
title: The Best of Creative Computing: Volume 1

description: Notone is a dice game played against the computer. On a turn a player can throw two dice as often as he or she wishes, adding each thrown value to the total for that turn. But if the player throws a one on any of the dice, the total for that turn equals zero. After ten rounds the player with the highest score wins.
title: Notone

description: Rabbit Chase is about catching a rabbit. In this turn based game the player must try to catch a rabbit by getting within 20 units of the rabbit. The player knows the current location of the rabbit and him/herself, in addition to the direction and speed of travel.

sample_screenshots.caption: Gameplay

title: Rabbit Chase

description: Geowar puts the player in control of a missile battery. Five enemy installations are located in a 30 by 30 area beyond the player's base, but never within 10 units. The player can fire missiles to try to hit the enemy installations. Missiles fly infinitely in the direction where shot and can hit multiple targets. When a missile just misses a target, the target will move one unit in any direction.

sample_screenshots.caption: Startscreen

title: Geowar

description: Seawar puts the player in charge of a fleet of nine ships with the task of destroying the enemy fleet. This might sound similar to Battleship, but there are some twists. First the player must give an angle of fire rather than a coordinate to fire at and there is a seven second time limit for each shot. The first to destroy all enemy ships wins.

sample_screenshots.caption: Startscreen

title: Seawar

description: Wumpus 3 is an adapted version of Wumpus 2. The core of the game remains identical with the player hunting a Wumpus in a cave system. It has the following additional random events: Earthquakes, bat migrations, and what is described as the "turnareo" which changes the layout of the cave.
title: Wumpus 3

description: Concentration is a memory game for a single player. The game uses a standard 52 card deck and each time a pair is made they are removed from play. The player has 26 turns in which to find all pairs.
title: Concentration

description: Road Race is a textual racing game. The player races the American Pittsfield-to-Albany road in a race car. The track is five miles long and the player has only half a gallon of gas. The player controls braking and acceleration and must react to changing conditions of the road such as cars that need to be overtaken. The goal is to make it to the end without crashing or running out of gas.
title: Road Race

description: Condot pits the player against the computer in a conversion of the pen and paper game Dots and Boxes. The player and computer take turns connecting dots on a grid with the aim of creating a box by providing the fourth line that makes up a box. The player then claims that box. Whoever has most boxes once all dots are connected wins the game.
title: Condot

description: Mastermind is a computer adaptation in BASIC of the well known board game. The computer has a code of four coloured pegs and the player must guess the code. After each guess the computer will inform the player of the amount of pegs which are of the right colour and which are in the right position. The goal is to guess the code in as few turns as possible.
title: Mastermind

description: Bobstones is a computer version of the dice game described in the novel Watership Down. The player plays against the computer and guesses the properties of two thrown dice. First the player must guess if the value is odd or even, then the sum of the dice and the individual values. The player can earn three points if everything is correct. The first player to collect 11 points wins the game.
title: Bobstones

description: Watchman is a puzzle game in which the player must patrol all streets as a watchman, but never retrace a street twice.
title: Watchman

description: Delmar is a horse betting game. Five horses will race, manned by variable jockeys. Depending on their handicap they will have different odds. The game can be played with multiple players and everyone can take a bet on each race with a starting budget of $100.
title: Delmar

description: Two-To-Ten is a card game similar to Black Jack. The player is dealt cards (with values in the range two to ten) and must try to get as close as possible to a random number determined at the start of the round. The player isn't told the exact limit, but only a value within 15% of the limit. The player also draws a lucky limit card which determines how close the player may come to the limit to win. The player goes bust if the limit is exceeded.
title: Two-To-Ten

description: Star Trek Trainer is a version of Star Trek that focuses on a single combat between the player's Federation Enterprise and a Klingon Battlecruiser. Each turn the player can choose between phasers and photon torpedoes. The ship can be maneuvered to get a better shot using warp and impulse drives. Deflector shields deteriorate when getting hit and when the player is losing he or she can try to maneuver out of sensor range to force a draw. The chance of hitting a shot depends on proximity to the target.
title: Star Trek Trainer

description: Realtrek is a version of Star Trek written in FORTRAN for the IBM 360 mainframe. The game differs from other variants of Star Trek in that it features a text parser that allows English sentences to enter commands. The game plays out in semi-real time and the Klingon ships have identical statistics to the player's Enterprise.
title: Realtrek

description: Blkjak is a digital implementation of the card game Blackjack. The player starts with some virtual cash and must try to earn more. The house limit is $500 and the computer pays out 1.5 to 1 on a Blackjack hand. The player receives cards and must try to get as close to a card value of twenty one without going bust. The computer also receives cards, whoever gets closest wins the wager. The player can split his or her hand when having two identical cards, but does not recognize five-cards-and-under.
title: Blkjak

description: Game Playing With Computers is a book detailing over 70 games, puzzles and mathematical creations. Over 25 of them have a source code in FORTRAN or BASIC included. Games include: Blackjack, binary card games, counterfeit coin game, Keno, Roulette, Go, Chess, Nim, Pentomino and Tic-Tac-Toe.
title: Game Playing With Computers

description:
The Best of Creative Computing: Vol. 2 compiles work from the second volume of the magazine Creative Computing. Included are some BASIC games listings:

  • Wumpus 2
  • War 3
  • Concentration
  • Condot
  • Chase
  • Mastermind
  • Deepspace
  • Bobstones
  • Watchman
  • Delmar
  • LEM
  • Two-To-Ten
title: The Best of Creative Computing: Vol. 2

description: The Planet Management Game is a computerized version of the educational simulation game of the same name released in 1971. Players through management of the planet Earth learn about contemporary issues such as pollution, famine and population explosion.
title: The Planet Management Game

description: The Mouse in the Maze: A Science Game is computerized version of the 1971 paper educational game of the same name. Players manipulate simulation settings to gain data on animal behaviour and learn to test hypotheses about their behaviour.
title: The Mouse in the Maze: A Science Game

description:
Advanced Star Trek is a Star Trek variant written for the IBM 370/158 in PL/I. The player controls the enterprise and will encounter Klingons, Romulans and Tholians. Klingons have two different ship types, Romulans are invisible and can follow the player unnoticed. Tholians attack in groups of three and have a web-like tractor beam. Another ship, the Fairy Queen is also available in emergencies.

The player goes hunting for enemies in a galaxy made up out of 10x10 quadrants which are again divided up into 10x10 sectors. The player can also travel through time, but this can have some serious consequences.
title: Advanced Star Trek

description: Air is a multiplayer air combat game. The game is played in quasi-real time and uses ASCII graphics to represent a three dimensional display. The game appeared in 1977 and was updated periodically until 1979.
title: Air

description: Mastermind: A Game of Logic is an officially licensed version of the board game Mastermind. The player must try to break a four color code by guessing the solution. After each guess the player will learn the number of colors that feature in that code, and which are in the right location, but the player must deduce to which colors it applies.
title: Mastermind: A Game of Logic

description: Yes-No Game is a number guessing game. The computer thinks of a number and the player must guess it in as few turns as possible. The player can ask questions in the vein of is it higher, lower or equal in value to. The computer can only answer with yes or no.
title: Yes-No Game

description:
Mine8 has the player cross a minefield. Each turn the player can choose in what direction to travel and for how long (with a limit of 8.5 seconds). The player sees only a limited distance and must reach the other side within three minutes. The distance the player covers depends on his pain level. There are multiple terrain types that impede vision or slow the player down (clear land, hills (slows player, but gives larger view), bushes (increase pain and reduce vision), ledges (cannot be passed), rocks (increase pain after long travel), lakes (the player must stop and can then start swimming).

Mines usually become visible when the player is near, but due to the turn based nature of the game it might be too late. Mines can have various effects: Stun the player, knock unconscious, break a limb, fling the player away, or instantly kill the player. Mines will also spin the player around making it hard for the player to see where he or she came from. The player can try to find tracks left behind in most terrain.

When the player reaches the end a map of the minefield can be printed which shows the path travelled by the player.
title: Mine8

description: Mini-Kalah is a computer adaptation of the ancient board game. The game uses a slightly smaller version of the board (only ten cups). The game can be played against the computer or another player. Each turn the player can pick a cup and redistribute the beads in that cup counter clockwise. Points are scored for beads that end up in the score cups. The match ends when there are no more beads to move. A game consists of two matches. The starting player switches between matches.
title: Mini-Kalah

description: Survivor is a strategy game for two players based on Conway's Game of Life. The players place initial cells on a 5x5 grid. Players don't know the starting position of the other player. After the initial input the board progresses one generation according to the rules of Conway's Game of Life. After each generation both players can place another cell on the board; if both pick the same spot neither is placed. The game ends when one player does not have any pieces left on the board after a generation.
title: Survivor

description: Peasant is a chess game that features only kings and pawns. The rules of chess remain the same. The game was written for AI research into the end game of a game of chess.
title: Peasant

description: Battle is a two player ballistics game. Player fire projectiles at each other from two different terminals on a HP 2000 mainframe.
title: Battle

description: Chess allows two players to play a game of chess against each other from two different terminals on a HP 2000 mainframe.
title: Chess

description: Machine/Menace is a tic-tac-toe game with an AI that's capable of learning the game. At the start of the first match the AI only knows the game is played in turns and a mark can only be placed in an empty square. After some games it will play a perfect game.
title: Machine/Menace

description: Keno is a computer implementation of the casino game. The player can pick an amount of numbers to take on a keno card and bets money on it. The players is then rewarded based on the numbers that are drawn.
title: Keno

description:
Marienbad is an adaptation of the strategy game Nim, originally written in Poland for the Odra 1003 mainframe. The game did not originally have a specific title; in later literature the name Marienbad was applied retroactively. It is one of the earliest Polish computer games. It was inspired by a variant of Nim seen in the 1961 movie Last Year at Marienbad and described under the name "Marienbad" in the magazine Przekrój.

There are several rows (four by default) of matchsticks, with a different number of matchsticks in each row. Both players (the human and the computer) take turns, in each move taking away at least one matchstick from a single row. The player left with the final matchstick loses.

sample_screenshots.caption: Full game print

title: Marienbad

description: Master Mind "Codemaker" is a typical text-based Mastermind game. The computer thinks of a code consisting of a sequence of colored pegs and the player must guess it in ten tries. After each guess the player is told the number of pegs that are in the code but in the wrong position and the pegs that are in the right position. The player must deduce to which pegs that refers.
title: Master Mind "Codemaker"

description: Monopoly is a computer version of the classic board game. The game is written in BASIC and allows play of the game with friends. There is no play against the computer. The computer can display all the property details and does all the book keeping so that players can focus on making decisions.
title: Monopoly

description: Nimble is a Nim variant written in BASIC. The player plays against the computer picking objects from different piles in an attempt to be the person to take the last object. In a turn a player can take as many objects as desired, but only from a single pile. The game features five difficulty levels and the starting player is decided randomly.
title: Nimble

description: Othello is a computer adaptation of the board game of the same name. On a eight by eight grid the player and computer take turns to place a marker on the board. Markers must be placed to enclose one or more markers of the opponent in one or more direction. Any enclosed markers change symbol to be identical to the enclosing marker symbol. After 60 moves, when the board is full whoever has most markers on the board wins the game. This implementation allows for a handicap to be set for players.
title: Othello

description: Dazzle Dart is a fictional sport in which two teams of two players compete and try to fire a beam of light into the opposing team's goal. Players can move forward and backward and rotate around their axis. Each player carries a giant mirror that deflects the beam of light. To score the beam of light must be deflected by at least one other player and hit the goal. Aside from shot the beam can also be passed to to the team mate, which is instant and cannot be blocked.
title: Dazzle Dart

description: BKG is a Backgammon playing computer program that runs on a PDP-10 mainframe computer. It plays a standard game and is renowned for having the first AI game program that ever beat a ruling world champion in any board game. The game could be played online of the ARPANET.
title: BKG

description: Duchess is a chess program. It runs on an IBM 370/168. The AI uses iterative deepening and searches roughly 200,000 nodes every three minutes. It knows 3,000 opening positions to get a game started after which the AI takes over. The game managed to reach the second place at the 1977 World Computer Chess Championship.
title: Duchess

description: Merlin is a chess program written in CDC Assembly for the CDC 6600. The game is derived from Chess 0.5. The AI was developed by students at the Vienna University of Technology.
title: Merlin

description: Chess 0.5 is a chess program designed to teach a player how to play. It's based roughly on Chess 4.x. The player can play chess against the AI and the author also encouraged using the code as a basis to build new chess programs.
title: Chess 0.5

description: Gesnumbr is a number guessing game. Unlike most of such games instead of just the player guessing, the player and computer take turns at guessing each other's number.
title: Gesnumbr

description: Mastermind plays the board game of the same name. The AI can both pose a code to the player or try to solve a code. Using the standard amount of permutations the AI will usually deduce the right code in four guesses. The game is written in FORTRAN.
title: Mastermind

description: Masterbagels is a game that combines elements from other code guessing games including Mastermind, Bagels and Bulls and Cows. At the start of a round the player determines the number of digits of the code, the maximum value of each digit and the amount of codes the player wants to guess. The game keeps averages for how many guesses it takes the player to guess the code.
title: Masterbagels

description: Strike 9 is a simple dice game. Each player starts with the numbers 1 to 9 and the goal is to play them all away. This is done by throwing two dice and summing their value. The player can then remove numbers which sum equals the dice roll. Whoever manages to remove all their starting numbers first wins the game.
title: Strike 9

description: Flip is a guessing game. The computer will think of either yes or no and the player must guess which. This is done 50 times and the goal is to get as many correct guesses as possible. However the computer will try to find patterns in the player's guessing routine to turn the odds to its favour.
title: Flip

description:
Twonky places the player in a 15x15 grid. The grid contains an objective tile, 30 blocked tiles, 22 relocation tiles, 1 tile which completely regenerates a new grid, and a Twonky, which must be avoided. The goal of the player is to reach the goal tile, without getting caught by the Twonky. The player and Twonky move one tile at a time. The Twonky ignores all special tiles. The player loses if the Twonky gets within two tiles of the player.

The game is completely text-based and the only way to find the special tiles is to stumble into them. The player is expected to keep his or her own map. The player can also try to fire at the Twonky with a ray-gun. When firing, the distance to the Twonky is shown. If the Twonky was in a straight line from the player it de-materializes, but also re-materializes at a new location in the maze. The player can use the distance output to determine where the Twonky is in relation to the player.
title: Twonky

description: Star Trek in ALGOL is a Star Trek variant written in ALGOL for the Burroughs 6700/7700 large system. In the game the player controls the USS Enterprise and must rid the galaxy of Klingons by exploring quadrants of the galaxy and firing phasers and torpedoes when getting in contact.
title: Star Trek in ALGOL

description:
Comput-O-Mat: Games / Brain Games is a compilation of games meant for libraries. The following games are included:

  • Horse Race
  • Craps
  • One-Armed Bandit
  • Tic-Tac-Toe
  • Blackjack
  • Bowling
  • Football
  • Cryptograms
  • Submarine Commander
  • Arithmetic Quiz
  • Stock Market
  • Guess
  • Lunar Lander
title: Comput-O-Mat: Games / Brain Games

description:
Comput-O-Mat: New Games is a compilation of games and programs meant for libraries. The following games are included:

  • Flying Saucers
  • Space Challenge
  • Ghost - a word game.
  • Hangman
  • Pizza Delivery Game
  • Game of Life
  • Wonderama Snake Can Game - as in the children's show, answer trivia and open cans to find the grand prize.
title: Comput-O-Mat: New Games

description:
Euchre is a computer implementation of two-handed Euchre in BASIC. The player plays against the computer. The goal is of the game is to earn 10 points. After each hand points up to four points are awarded. The game uses a 24 card deck and each player is dealt 12 cards, four face up, four face down and four in the hand. One of the players must call a trump suit. Players then play cards to win tricks, where trump takes all. The player that called trump must win at least seven tricks to get points, otherwise the other player will earn points based on the number of tricks.

The AI doesn't have a robust strategy, but cheats by looking at all 12 cards before calling trump and looking at the player's hand when leading a card.
title: Euchre

description: Bocce is a simulation of the Italian ball game with similarities to the French pétanque or lawn bowls. The game starts with the smaller "jack" ball at a random position in the play field. The players are divided into two teams and on their turn must throw a ball by giving a velocity and angle. When all balls are thrown the team whose ball is closest to the jack scores points. Ball can also hit each other and knock each other away. When this happens a bell is rung. The DEC BASIC version of the game is fully text-based and prints the coordinates of each ball are shown, but the game allows for showing a graphical overview when hooked up to a Tektronix 4006-1 video terminal.
title: Bocce

description: The Congressional Game is an educational game for secondary school and college students. The game simulates the US congress from a century ago. The educational value lies in understanding how congress and historians work. The game presents various historical facts including a Korean seizure of an American naval vessel, civil rights, import tariffs and railroad subsidies on a federal level. Players must use provided information to develop a hypothesis on the outcome of a roll-call vote. The winner of the game is the student who most accurately hypothesises the results of congressional votes.
title: The Congressional Game

description: Nomad I has the player visiting his or her grandmother. At the start of each games she sends a telegram to the player with her (randomized) address in Garbonzo city. It's up to the player to move there without getting caught for speeding, running out of gas or getting hit by a drunk driver.
title: Nomad I

description: Othello is an implementation of the classic board game in FORTRAN. The player plays against the computer. The game takes place on an 8x8 grid and the player and computer take turns placing pieces of their color on the board next to an existing piece. Any pieces enclosed by pieces of your color switch color and become yours. Whoever owns most pieces when the board is filled wins the game.
title: Othello

description: Yahtzee is an implementation of the classic dice game. The game allows play for up to seven players. All the usual rules apply. On a turn a player rolls five dice and can re-roll (a selection) twice. Scoring is divided in multiples of a value (amount of aces, twos, threes, etc.) and special rolls such as full house and Yahtzee (5 identical dice). After each turn the player must decide what to write, or strike out one of the available options if nothing matches. Getting at least 63 points with multiples will yield a bonus score of 35 points. Whoever scores the most points at the end wins.
title: Yahtzee

description: Oil Company is a business simulation. The player has just inherited an oil company and must try to invest money wisely to keep the business profitable. For a configurable number of years. Each year the player can perform commands, such as purchasing crude oil, export refined products, build new refineries, refine crude oil, drill for new wells (on a grid), sell wells and refineries. At the end of each year the player receives royalties in the form of money and crude oil. Prices fluctuate over time and disasters can throw in unpredicted results.
title: Oil Company

description: Star Wars simulates an attack on the Death Star. The player must run the trench and fire a proton torpedo into its exhaust shaft to destroy it. In the meanwhile three tie fighters are in play. One continuously follows the player while the other two move randomly. The game plays in turns. At each turn the player must give a command (move left, right, up, down, fire or pull out). Also the player is given a front and back view from his cockpit showing the location of the shaft and the chasing tie fighters.
title: Star Wars

description: Van Gam is an implementation of Van Wythoff's Game. There are two piles of matches and the player and computer take turns removing matches. In a turn the player can either take one or more matches from one pile or an identical number from both piles. The person to take the last match wins.
title: Van Gam

description: Racetrack is a top-down racing game for two players. Aside from the two players there are also two computer controlled opponents which drive a predefined path. The track has many curves and features oil slicks to further complicate things. The game is played in turns with the player giving a direction, acceleration and gear. Depending on the screen size the game can be played with a fixed screen or scrolling track.
title: Racetrack

description: Casino: A Small System Simulator is a simulation of roulette written in COMAL. The game is written mostly as a tutorial for the COMAL language. The game does not use actual roulette rules, instead the player bets on one of five colors and wins or loses if that color is drawn randomly. The game detects when the player tries to break the rules (e.g. tries to bet negative or zero values or bets more money than the player has). When the player breaks the rules too often he's removed from the game.
title: Casino: A Small System Simulator

description: Dark Horse is a chess program written in FORTRAN and running on a CDC 6600 mainframe and later on a UNIVAC 1100. It plays a standard game of chess and competed in world and European computer chess championships. The program was the runner-up in the 1979 European computer chess championship.
title: Dark Horse

description: Craps is a simulation of the casino game. The game uses standard Las Vegas style rules and is written in BASIC. The player places a bet and then rolls the dice. When rolling a value of seven or eleven the bet is won. The bet is lost when rolling a value of two, three or twelve. Rolling something else it's a point and the player must roll that again, but cannot roll seven any more.
title: Craps

description: Multiple Lunar Lander is a compilation of various implementations of Lunar Lander written in BASIC.
title: Multiple Lunar Lander

description: Slot Machine is a simulation of a casino slot machine. The player gambles virtual money in the hope to increase earnings.
title: Slot Machine

description:
Game Package is a compilation featuring three games written in BASIC:

  • Russian Roulette - Simulation of a revolver with a single bullet in it.
  • Mad Scientist - No information is known about this game.
  • ABM - Fire anti-ballistic missiles.
title: Game Package

description: Jacpot is a simulation of a slot machine. The player can decide how much money to start with and after each set of spins is asked how many more spins should be taken. The values on the spinners all have computer related terms on them. Different terms have different probabilities of appearing. Only certain combinations pay out, and some make the player lose money. The player also sees the amount of money still in the device.
title: Jacpot

description: Misfit is a puzzle game for up to five players. Words appear on the screen, after each word all players can either pass or strike. When everybody passes, the next word is revealed. When someone strikes that person must name the word that doesn't fit in the group. If the guess is correct the player can "nab" or "stab" at the commonality of the other words. When taking a stab and the guess is correct the player earns two points. When taking a nab, another player must guess the commonality of the words, if that player doesn't know the nabbing player wins two points. Points are represented by the letters of the word misfit. The first player to collect the whole word wins the game.
title: Misfit

description: Hex is a strategy played against the computer. At the start, there is a variable sized play field, ranging from 3x3 to 11x21 hexagons in a diamond form. The player and computer put a mark on the board each turn with the goal of connecting two sides of the board in a continuous string.
title: Hex

description: Hodge is a word search game written in the educational programming language PILOT. The player must find words in a grid of letters. Words can be in the grid horizontally, vertically and backwards. The player types in the words found which are then removed from the grid.
title: Hodge

description: Starwars Hodge is an updated version of Hodge, a word search game written in PILOT. This version features only terms from the first Star Wars movie.
title: Starwars Hodge

description: Wander (included game) is a tool for creating interactive fiction. It was continuously updated into the 1980s. It comes with one text adventure called Castle. The player wanders around without much of a goal exploring locations such as a forest, orchard, missile silo and a castle. The player types text to go places and pick stuff up or otherwise interact with elements in the environment. There is no scoring.
title: Wander (included game)

description: Hide and Seek is a mathematical puzzle in which four players are hidden in a grid. The player guesses coordinates and is told the distance to each of the players. After ten guesses the player must have found them all. The game is a predecessor of Mugwump.
title: Hide and Seek

description:
Aldebarran III is a text adventure written in the Wander system. The game is based on the satirical short stories about Jame Retief by Keith Laumer. The player takes on the role of Retief who works for the Corps Diplomatique Terrestrienne. Retief is sent to Aldebarran III to avert an uprising against Terran nationals.

The player starts in a customs building and can explore the spaceport and other buildings on Aldebaran III. Exploration is done using a text parser with verb noun commands.
title: Aldebarran III

description: Phantnum (portmanteau for phantom numbers) is an educational game written in APL. The game requires knowledge of elementary mathematics to find "phantom numbers" disguised as letters. All numbers are replaced by letters. The player may input functions using "plus", "minus" and "times" and get an answer. Using these results the player must infer which letter corresponds with which number.
title: Phantnum

description: Chaos is a chess program written in FORTRAN. The name is an acronym for "Chess Heuristics And Other Stuff". The program participated in 12 North American Computer Chess Championships and four world chess championships. Development started in the late 60s at RCA and later continued at the University of Michigan. It was continuously developed until the mid 80s.
title: Chaos

description: Black Knight is a chess program written in FORTRAN that runs on a UNIVAC 1100 computer. The program played four American Computer Chess Championships from 1975 to 1978 and one World Computer Chess Championship in 1977.
title: Black Knight

description: Xenarbor is a chess program written in Fortran and running on an IBM 370 (and later on a IBM 3081). The program played at the American Computer Chess tournaments in 1974, 1976, 1977 and 1984.
title: Xenarbor

description: Ostrich is a chess program. Initially it ran on a Data General Supernova mainframe, but in 1982 it became the first chess program to run on multiple mainframes in parallel. The name of the program refers to the head-in-the-sand tactics the AI employs in times of crisis. The program played fifteen American Computer Chess tournaments and the first five World Computer Chess Championships from 1972 to 1987.
title: Ostrich

description: Daly CP is a chess program written in assembly. The program played at the first United States Computer Chess Championship in 1970, finishing second place. Unlike most chess programs which dialed in to a remote mainframe, the workstation was on-site and used a graphical user interface with a pen input device.
title: Daly CP

description: Coko (the Cooper-Kozdrowicki chess program) is a chess program written in FORTRAN. It participated in three American computer chess championships (1970, 1971 and 1972). Later versions included the Mater software which is a dedicated piece of software to detect check-mate situations: both how to cause them and how to prevent them.
title: Coko

description: J. Biit (standing for: "just because it is there") is a chess program written in PL/I. The program played in the first United States Computer Chess Championship in 1970. It uses a graphical user interface which was uncommon at the time. The UI was later improved and used for the chess program CCCP.
title: J. Biit

description: Genie is a chess program written in QSPL. The program played on the second United States Computer Chess Championship in 1971.
title: Genie

description: David is a chess program developed at the Graz University of Technology in Austria. The program played in the second United States Computer Chess Championship in 1971.
title: David

description: CCCP (Columbia Computer Chess Program) is a chess program written in PL/I. The game played at the second United States Computer Chess Championship in 1971. The game's graphical user interface evolved from the earlier J. Biit.
title: CCCP

description: Leverett CP is a chess program running on a PDP-10. The program participated in the third United States Computer Chess Program in 1972, reaching the last place.
title: Leverett CP

description: USC CP is a chess program developed at the University of Southern California. The program participated in two North American Chess Championships in 1972 and 1973. The AI uses pattern recognition of various manually entered patterns on the board which are scored.
title: USC CP

description: MSU CP is a chess program developed at the Mississippi State University. The program participated in the third North American Chess Championship in 1972.
title: MSU CP

description: Dartmouth CP is a chess program written in GCOS assembly at Dartmouth College. The program played at the 1973 North American Computer Chess Championship and again in 1974 under the name Dart.
title: Dartmouth CP

description: Ga Tech CP is a chess program developed at Georgia Tech. The program played at the 1973 North American Computer Chess Championship.
title: Ga Tech CP

description: The Fox is a chess program written in APL. The program played at the 1973 North American Computer Chess Championship. It managed to win the first match, but lose the other two due to timeouts because of too many users on the timesharing system on which the program ran.
title: The Fox

description: Ches is a chess program. It played at the 1973 North American Computer Chess Championship and ended up in the last place.
title: Ches

description: Tyro is a chess program and successor to USC CP. It played at the North American Computer Chess Championships of 1974, 1975 and 1977.
title: Tyro

description: Chute (acronym for: CHess, University of Toronto, Engineering) is a chess program written at the University of Toronto. The program played in four North American Computer Chess Championships from 1974 to 1977 and the World Computer Chess championship in Toronto in 1977.
title: Chute

description: Atlas is a chess program, originally written on and for the Atlas supercomputer. The program was later ported to ALGOL. During most of its existence it was the only chess playing programming in the UK.
title: Atlas

description: Lancaster is a chess program. It's the second chess program developed in the UK. It played an exhibition match against Mac Hack VI in 1968 as well as playing against the only other English chess program at the time: Atlas.
title: Lancaster

description: Master (Minimax Algorithm, teSTER) is a chess program written in PL/I and based on Atlas. The program played at the World Computer Chess Championship in Stockholm in 1974.
title: Master

description: Freedom is a chess program running on a CDC Cyber. The program played at the first World Computer Chess Championship in Stockholm in 1974.
title: Freedom

description: Tell is a chess program. The program played at the first two World Computer Chess Championships in 1974 and 1977 as well as the first German Computer Chess Tournament in 1975, which it won.
title: Tell

description: Ribbit is a chess program written in Fortran. The program played at the first world computer chess championship in 1974 and placed second. It also won the 1974 American Computer Chess Championship. The program was later replaced by the upgraded Treefrog.
title: Ribbit

description: Treefrog is a chess program written in Fortran. The program played at the 1975 American Computer Chess Championship and placed second. The program was an upgraded version of Ribbit.
title: Treefrog

description: Kches is a chess program running on an HP 2000C mainframe. The program (version 6) competed at the North American Computer Chess Championship in 1974 but withdrew after two losses.
title: Kches

description: Fischer-Schneider is a chess program developed at the University of Stuttgart. The program is written in assembly. In 1975 the program played at the first German Computer Chess Tournament.
title: Fischer-Schneider

description: Daja is a chess program. The program was a runner-up at the 1975 German Computer Chess Championship. The program later evolved to become Elsa.
title: Daja

description: Elsa is a chess program and successor to Daja. The program participated at the 1977 World Computer Chess Championship.
title: Elsa

description: Frantz is a chess program that runs on a 30-bit UNIVAC 494. The program played at the 1st World Computer Chess Championship.
title: Frantz

description: A16chs is a chess program developed for the Alpha16 minicomputer. The program participated at the first World Computer Chess Championship in 1974.
title: A16chs

description: Papa is a chess program that applies the concept of entropy on piece mobility. The program participated at the first World Computer Chess Championship in 1974, losing all games.
title: Papa

description: Charlie is a chess program written in assembly and LIDIA. The program played at the first German Computer Chess Championship in 1975 and the first European Computer Chess Championship in 1976.
title: Charlie

description: ETAOIN SHRDLU is a chess program running on a Nova 1200 minicomputer. The game competed at the American Computer Chess Championships in 1975 and 1976. The name refers to the most commonly used letters in the English letters which also form the first two columns of common type-casting machine keyboards.
title: ETAOIN SHRDLU

description: Iron Fish is a chess program running on a CDC Cyber and successor to Mr. Turk. The game played at the 1975 American Computer Chess Championship.
title: Iron Fish

description: Sortie is a chess program. The program played at the 1975 American Computer Chess Championship and finished last.
title: Sortie

description: Schach MV is a chess program written in FORTRAN. The program uses a SOMA approach (Smith One-Move Analyzer) and never looks ahead more than one ply (turn for both players). Development started in 1971 and competed at the first German Computer Chess Tournament in 1975.
title: Schach MV

description: Samiel is a chess program running on an IBM 370/168 mainframe. The program competed in the first German Computer Chess Tournament in 1975.
title: Samiel

description: Proscha (short for Projekt Schach) is a chess program written in PL/I at the University of Dortmund. The program played at the first German Computer Chess Tournament in 1975.
title: Proscha

description: Blitz is a chess program written in FORTRAN. The program played at four American Computer Chess Championships and one World Computer Chess Championship from 1976 to 1979 running on UNIVAC mainframes. The program was succeeded by Cray Blitz in 1980.
title: Blitz

description: Cray Blitz is a chess program running on Cray hardware such as the Cray-1 supercomputer, Cray X-MP, Cray Y-MP and C916. The program was specifically designed to use multiple processors (16 on the C916). The program was written in FORTRAN with parts in Assembly Language. Twice Cray Blitz won the North American Computer Chess Championship and also twice it won the World Computer Chess Championship (in 1983 and 1986). It's a successor to Blitz.
title: Cray Blitz

description: Bs'66'76 is a chess program developed between 1966 and 1976 in FORTRAN. The program was developed as part of a thesis and played at the 1976 European Computer Chess Championship, the 1977 World Computer Championship and North American Computer Chess Championships of 1978 and 1979, as well as various Dutch tournaments afterwards.
title: Bs'66'76

description: L'Excentrique is a chess program for Amdahl mainframe computers. The game played at various North American Computer Chess Championships from 1976 to 1981 and at the Third World Computer Chess Championship in 1980 where it placed fourth.
title: L'Excentrique

description: Chesstar is a chess program. The program played at the 1976 North American Computer Chess Championship running from a Honeywell x16.
title: Chesstar

description: Brute Force is a chess program. The program participated at the North American Computer Chess Championships of 1977 and 1978.
title: Brute Force

description: Finesse is a chess program. The program played against Brute Force in 1975 at the University of Manitoba.
title: Finesse

description: Gomoku is a computer implementation of the Japanese five-in-a-row board game. Players take turns placing pieces on a Go board, with the aim of being the first to have an uninterrupted chain of five in a row.
title: Gomoku

description: Othello is a computer implementation of the board game of the same name. Players take turns placing tokens on the board, tokens that are surrounded by two tokens of another color change color. When the board is full, the player with the most tokens of their color on the board wins the game.
title: Othello

description: Alder is a Dutch chess program. The program played a first unofficial Dutch computer chess match running from a PDP-11/45.
title: Alder

description: PLAYBJ is a computerized version of the game of Black Jack. The player plays against the bank (the computer) drawing cards with the intent of getting a value of 21 without going over. The game is designed as a teaching aid for learning to play better. The game simulates typical Las Vegas casino rules.
title: PLAYBJ

description:
METRO-APEX is an educational game about county planning designed for students of Environmental Science and Forestry.

The game familiarizes players with real-life situations which include the environmental and political aspects students might encounter in their career in the fictional Apex county.

The game is played with multiple players, each is given different roles such as planners, politicians, industrialists, pressure groups, lawyers, judges, press and broadcast media, each with their own goals. There are no specific win or lose cases for the game, but the politicians can win or lose elections, litigants can win or lose suits and industrialists can make profit or losses.

Players must role-play their role and enter their actions into the computer after which the computer feeds back the results of actions. This includes a weekly newspaper. Player actions constitute a complete year of policy decisions for their role.
title: METRO-APEX

description:
The Sumerian Game is an early computer game played by teletype and video projector. While mostly forgotten by history it did inspire the game Hamurabi which became hugely popular in the late 60s and early 70s. The game is designed for fourth grade students.

In the game the player rules as three successive rulers of the Sumerian city-state of Lagash. During the reign of each ruler the player must make decisions, mostly of an economic nature to sustain the population. Visuals such as graphs and charts help the players understand the economic concepts. The video projector would show slide shows which were combined with tape audio. The tape audio would contain simulated discussion of the king's cabinet and news bulletins, which served as intermezzos to the economic reports which were all in printed format. All player actions were typed in on the teletype. A court adviser gives advice on actions and makes sure actions are executed.

The script of the game was revised multiple times until funding ran out in 1967.
title: The Sumerian Game

description: Astro-64 is a Romanian chess program that ran on a Felix C-256 mainframe. It's mostly known for a match it played against newspaper readers. each week readers could propose a new move and the computer would generate a counter move that would go into print the next week.
title: Astro-64

description: PAASLOW is a checkers program developed at Duke University in North Carolina. It is the first checkers program that managed to defeat a Grandmaster checker player. The game implements the typical rules where players take turn moving their pieces which can only move diagonally or jump diagonally over opposing pieces. Pieces that reach the other side of the board are kinged and can move backwards and move any amount of units in a move.
title: PAASLOW

description: Lucas' Puzzle is a solitaire peg puzzle originally invented by the French mathematician Édouard Lucas. A number of pegs is placed on a one dimensional board. Pegs on the right of the board can only move left and vice versa. The goal is to move all the pegs on the right to the left and vice versa. The puzzle can be solved in 24 moves.
title: Lucas' Puzzle

description: Adventure also known as Adventure-501 is a 501-point updated version of the original Adventure game. Like the original the game plays like a typical early text-adventure. Where the player must explore different areas to collect treasure and bring it all to a specific room. To gain the treasure puzzles must be solved. The game builds on the original game, but changes some of the puzzles and adds new areas including a large outdoors area.
title: Adventure

description: Library is a text adventure written in the Wander system. The player explores a library based on the Widener Library at Harvard University. The setting is post-apocalyptic and the goal like in many early text adventures is to collect treasures while solving puzzles.
title: Library

description: Tic-Tac-Toe with a Twist is a Tic-Tac-Toe game written in BASIC. The player plays against the computer. The twist is that the computer uses an imperfect AI routine, meaning the player can win every game once the logic error is deduced.
title: Tic-Tac-Toe with a Twist

description: Pico-Fumi is a logical deduction game similar to Mastermind played against the computer. Both the player and computer pick a two digit number and must guess the other's. After each guess the number of Pico (correct numbers in the wrong position) and Fumi (correct numbers in the right position) is given. The first player to guess the other's number wins the game.
title: Pico-Fumi

description:
This game simulates a malaria epidemic and your battle against it, in one or more five-year periods. You have several options, including * isolating those ill in quarantine hospitals; * provide medicine for those ill, and preventive drugs to the healthy; and * fighting mosquitos using various chemicals (DDT, Malathion, Propoxur) in various intensities.

Each of these has a price; the game allows you to play with or without budget. You have to decide which of these methods to use in which of the next five years.

The game then simulates the effectiveness of your measures and displays the number of deaths and sick people for each year, and optionally gives you an evaluation of the effectiveness of these measures. You then can go on for the next five years.
title: MALAR

alternate_titles.title: FRON: A Computerized Futuristic Simulation Game

description:
FRON v4.0 is a multi-player space game built on the IBM System 360 mainframe at UCLA. The user interface was developed by Frank Wood, and the internal logic was coded by Don Worth.

Gameplay involves exploration of a randomly generated map of stars. As a player-vs-player game, players take turns plotting moves on their part of the map. Map visibility is limited to the area currently occupied by the player and adjacent squares; enemy ship movement in other areas is unknown, while still being tracked by the computer. Because it is played over dial-up on the ARPANET, there is an overnight delay between moves. The game map is printed out via Teletype.

According to the game's creator, Don Worth, FRON was backed up on a 9-track mainframe tape, which is no longer extant.

sample_screenshots.caption: Close up of game map - credit: Don Worth
Full gameplay map - credit: Don Worth

title: FRON v4.0

description: Air-Battle Model is a war simulation game that's supported by a computer. The game was used by the United States Air Force's Air Battle Analysis Division from 1957. The game simulates a two-sided global war and the simulation covers offensive and defensive air and ground support operations in the first two days of war. The computer keeps constant track of war capabilities for both sides of the war so that the results of the game could be used to assess strategies or as an educational tool.
title: Air-Battle Model

description: Adventure is a version of the genre defining text adventure game Adventure. The game borrows much of the original ideas in terms of layout and puzzles, but changes almost everything else, such as room descriptions, the specifics of puzzles, the directions you can move in etc.
title: Adventure

description: Adventure is an extended version of the genre defining text adventure game Adventure. Where in the original game 350 points could be earned by solving the various puzzles, this version adds additional content for up to 430 points. Originally written in FORTRAN the game was later ported to C.
title: Adventure

description: Adventure is an extended version of the genre defining text adventure game Adventure. Where in the original game 350 points could be earned by solving the various puzzles, this version adds additional content for up to 550 points. To make room for the additional points this version adds 110 new rooms to explore and 11 new treasures to find.
title: Adventure

description: Educational Dungeon is a version of Dungeon, extended for educational purposes. The game would present questions to the player that required a correct answer to propel the story forward.
title: Educational Dungeon

description: Parwell is a chess program running on the Siemens SMS 201, using 128 8080 processors. Developed at the Technical University of Munich it was written in FORTRAN and 8080 Assembly and played European and world computer chess tournaments in 1979 and 1980.
title: Parwell

description: Gold Mine places the player in the role of a miner with the goal of mining as much gold as possible. The game is played in turns and each turn the player can mine at the current location or move to new locations (in the four cardinal directions) and try to find gold ore there. There are 100 veins of gold to be found in the mine. The game is played in mostly text, but the player can call up a visual map of the mine to see where the player needs to go to find the ore.
title: Gold Mine

description: Space Maze places the player in control of a space ship. The player must find a path past ten robot sentries to reach a space station. The sentries will fire at and destroy the player if the player comes within 1000 kilometers of them. Each turn the player gets a printout of the distance to each of the sentries and the space station. The player can then input the desired velocity, direction (using theta [0-180] and phi [0-360] in degrees) and time interval. The game will then update the printout and/or notify the player if the ship has been destroyed by a sentry.
title: Space Maze

description: Rasputin is a chess program developed at Westfield College, London. It can be considered as a predecessor to Merlin by the same author. The AI uses a Swapping Off Material Analyzer (SOMA) approach to finding the best move. It played in the European Computer Chess Championship in 1979.
title: Rasputin

description: Ringen is a text adventure that takes place in the world of Middle Earth and takes a lot of references from The Lord of the Rings. The player types in text commands to travel through different destinations and solve puzzles. Each location comes with a textual description. The game's text is in Norwegian.
title: Ringen

description: Buck Rogers Rides Again is an unlicensed Buck Rogers game. The player receives a distress call from a damaged space ship that's orbiting a black hole. The ship's reactor is about to blow so the player has only limited turns to save the crew. To save the crew, the player must stay within a limited distance of the ship for two consecutive turns. The game is text based and movement of the ships is described in two dimensions. Each turn, the coordinates and velocities of both ships are printed and the player can change the acceleration in two dimensions to synchronize the player's orbit with that of the ship in distress.
title: Buck Rogers Rides Again

description: Two Diamonds is a peg jumping puzzle game. The board consists of two diamonds with two different pegs (* and x). Each peg can move to an empty spot or jump over another peg to an empty spot. Pegs aren't removed, but the goal is to end up in a situation where all * pegs have moved to the diamond previously occupied by the x-es and vice versa.
title: Two Diamonds

description:
The Game of Life is an implementation of Conway's game of Life written in the programming language APL. It has patterns evolve using the normal rules:

  • Any live cell with fewer than two live neighbours dies, as if caused by under-population.
  • Any live cell with two or three live neighbours lives on to the next generation.
  • Any live cell with more than three live neighbours dies, as if by overcrowding.
  • Any dead cell with exactly three live neighbours becomes a live cell, as if by reproduction.
title: The Game of Life

description: Cribbage is an implementation of the classic card/board game written in BASIC. The player plays against the computer and is dealt a hand of six cards. Two cards must be laid into the crib. During a round cards are played and their total added up. The value of the added value cannot exceed 31 or the other player scores a point. If a player manages to get to exactly 31 two points are scored. Additional points can be scored for getting exactly 15, playing a pair, a triplet, double pair or run. After all cards are played players score additional points for all combinations that can be made with their hand, including a card cut at the start. The dealer gets additional points from combinations made with the crib cards.
title: Cribbage

description: Interim.2 is a Go-playing AI. The objective for development of the AI was to model human play styles and replication of human perceptual and cognitive abilities by modeling pattern recognition.
title: Interim.2

description: GREMEX, an acronym for the Goddard Research and Engineering Management Exercise, is a management training game. Players are tasked with seeing through a fictional project from the initial plans to the final construction phase. Depending on player input in monthly turns the expected completion date may move forward or back. The aim of the program is to give management a larger understanding of all the factors that can influence a project during its lifecycle. It was developed for NASA at the Goddard Space Flight Center but later became commercially available for other companies.
title: GREMEX

description: Bball: A Baseball Simulation is a baseball simulation game. The player plays a match against the computer. The computer and player have identical teams and the computer will even match the lineup, but the player has the advantage of being able to change strategies at any time, while the computer decides its entire strategy up front. The player can change strategies at any time and also substitute players a limited number of times.
title: Bball: A Baseball Simulation

description: Animal is a guessing game in which the computer guesses an animal the player is thinking about. The computer asks yes or no questions to the player until it can deduce which animal it is. If it fails to guess the animal it will ask for an identifying question it could've asked and the new animal and question is added to the database. This will allow the game to learn to identify more and more animals the players are thinking of.
title: Animal

description: Niche is an educational game about a biological ecosystem. The player is tasked with making an organism survive in its environmental niche for five generations. The organism will prosper when there's an abundance of food, lack of predators and little competition. The player can choose from a number of animals and then must try to specify the niche it will live in, by defining the type of environment, size of the environment and predators available in the environment.
title: Niche

description: Hvolt is a game that builds on game concepts of the game Chase. The player is placed within a field 10x20 tiles big. The player can move horizontally, vertically and diagonally. A number of enemy interceptors (between 15 and 35) are also placed on the field. These interceptors will do the exact same move as the player (space permitting). The goal is to guide them all to collision with high voltage poles which destroys them. Up to half a dozen attackers are also present on the field. They have a random personality which determines the rules with which they can attack. The attackers cannot move. The game features four difficulty levels.
title: Hvolt

description: Fort is a tactical game in which the player must defend a fort from native Americans that are attacking it. The player must last for 10 turns before friendly cavalry will arrive to drive the native Americans away. The game starts with the player having 30 troops defending each of the four sides of the wall. 400 native Americans are attacking each side of the fort. Each turn the player can decide from various tactical actions, such as letting a side attack (with cannon or guns), move men and/or cannonballs from one side to another. Each turn the Native Americans will move closer and kill some of the player's men. If the player manages to survive until the cavalry arrives the game is won.
title: Fort

description: French Military Game is a tactical game about maneuvering pieces on a small game board. The board consists of 11 locations on a capsule shaped board. The white player has three units starting at one end of the capsule and the black player has one unit starting in the middle. Both players can move one unit each turn. The white player must try to block the black player from making a valid move in which case white wins. The black player must try to reach the part of the capsule where white starts. Black can move in any direction, but white is never allowed to move back towards their origin. In this computer adaptation the player controls the white player.
title: French Military Game

description: Reversi is a BASIC implementation of Othello. The player and computer take turns placing a token on the board. Tokens of the other player that are enclosed by two tokens of the other player's color change color. When the whole board is filled whichever player has the most tokens of their color on the board wins the game.
title: Reversi

description: Rocket Launcher Program is a simulation game in which the player can attempt to launch a rocket into space and into orbit of the Earth. The game starts with a request for the player to input all specifications of the rocket (such as number of stages, fuel to hull weight ratio) and intended orbit altitude. The player must continuously update the throttle, firing angle and burn time to make the rocket move in the right direction.
title: Rocket Launcher Program

description: United States War Game: East Versus West places the player in command of either the Eastern or Western United States in a fictional civil war in contemporary times. At the start of the game the player can place a single base of operations, five missile sites and four mines. The player can use armies to try to conquer enemy territory or defend their base. The game is over if one of the players loses their base. Mines can be placed to defend the base as they will destroy the first army that steps on them. The base empowers nearby armies, making it more important to not hide the base too far away from the front lines. Missiles can be used to fire on anything within range. The player cannot see what goes on in enemy territory, but has full vision over their own half of the US.
title: United States War Game: East Versus West

description: Plunc is a Gomoku program running on a PDP 11/45 mainframe. The game managed to win a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Plunc

description: Arthur is a Gomoku program running on a IBM 370/158 mainframe. The game managed to get to second place in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Arthur

description: Gomoku is a Gomoku program running on a Xerox 530 mainframe. The game managed to reach third place in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Gomoku

description: Shifty is a Gomoku program running on an IBM 370/155 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Shifty

description: Phantom is a Gomoku program running on a PDP 10 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Phantom

description: Winr is a Gomoku program running on an Microdata mini computer. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Winr

description: Five-In-A-Row is a Gomoku program running on a PDP 8 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Five-In-A-Row

description: Gomokuis a Gomoku program running on an IBM 370/158 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Gomoku

description: Shein is a Gomoku program running on an IBM 370/158 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Shein

description: Dementia is a Gomoku program running on an IBM 370/155 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Dementia

description: Fred is a Gomoku program running on an IBM 370/155 mainframe. The game competed in a computer Gomoku championship in 1976. Gomoku is a game of five-in-a-row where players take turn placing pieces on a 19x19 grid. The first player to manage to get five pieces in a row, horizontally, vertically or diagonally wins the game.
title: Fred

description: Adventure/3000 is a version of the original Adventure for the HP3000. The game is written in HP3000 BASIC and tries to be a direct copy of the version the author played at MIT's timeshare computers. The game is a text adventure in which the player explores a cave system and surroundings to find various objects and treasures, creatures and puzzles. The player interacts with the world using short phrases. Solving puzzles scores the player points.
title: Adventure/3000

description: Galaxy II is a computer-moderated play-by-mail wargame. Each game features fifteen to thirty players, all commanding a different race. Races have different characteristics, leaders, behavior and a different starting point on the galactic map. A large part of the game consist of retaining diplomatic relationships with other races. The other part of the game consist of managing ships and planets controlled by the player's race. Probes can be used to find out information about other planets. Ships can be upgraded with different modules and the player can invest in colonies on different planets to increase their efficiency. The game ends once two players have been eliminated.
title: Galaxy II

description: Starbase 2300 is a simplified version of the complex play-by-mail wargame Galaxy II. The game retains its play-by-mail characteristics but simplifies some of the mechanics for a more streamlined game. The game also costs less per turn to play.
title: Starbase 2300

description: Conquer Post-Nuclear World is a play-by-mail game with computer moderation. In the game players compete to conquer a post-apocalyptic Earth. Players move their armies around and conquer land, bombing cities and build new military bases.
title: Conquer Post-Nuclear World

description:
Computer Programs that Work! is a book containing multiple computer programs including some games:

  • Battleships
  • Cars
  • Chomp
  • Drag - A drag racing game where two cars try to beat each other on a quarter mile straight. Instead of racing the player inputs the parameters of their car.
  • Fruit Machine - A slot machine simulation.
  • Mastermind - A licensed version of the classic board game.
