  • Spies - A game in which 10 Russian spies are hidden in a 10x10 grid. After each guess the distance to the remaining spies is given.
  • Timm - A Nim variant in which the player and computer take turns taking objects from different rows. The player to take the last object wins the game.
title: Computer Programs that Work!

description: Cars is a turn-based racing game where the player must complete a lap at Brands Hatch circuit. At each of 22 steps along the track the player receives a description of the situation and must input the gear, brake and accelerator values they wish to apply at that point. The goal is to finish the lap as quickly as possible without crashing.
title: Cars

description: Battleships is a game based on the pen and paper game Battleship, but with a twist. The game is played by a single player against the computer. The computer has positioned their fleet on a grid. The player fires at their opponent's grid in an attempt to destroy their fleet. The players can't see the ships, but did receive a map containing the positions of enemy ships. However only a single position of each ship is shown, regardless of their grid size and the map can be either mirrored or rotated allowing for additional deductive work to be done. The player has 25 rounds of ammunition to destroy the enemy fleet with.
title: Battleships

description: Nim Game is a typical implementation of the ancient game. The player and computer can pick one or more matches from a pile in turns. The player who takes the last item loses the game. The player can determine the number of piles and amount of matches per pile or can let the computer randomize it.
title: Nim Game

description:
57 Practical Programs & Games in BASIC is a book describing a large number of BASIC programs that can be typed into a computer. The games include:

  • Blackjack - A computer implementation of the classic card game.
  • Craps - A computer implementation of the casino dice game.
  • Number Guess Game - A simple number guessing game, where the player is informed if the guess is too high or too low.
  • One-Arm Bandit - A slot machine gambling game with randomized payout.
  • Space Wars (1) - A text-based one-on-one space duel where the player must try to shoot the enemy ship. The player has two weapons and can self destruct in case the situation becomes hopeless.
  • Space Wars (2) - A text-based death star trench run simulation.
title: 57 Practical Programs & Games in BASIC

description: Star Ship Simulation is a book containing a type-in game for a star ship simulation game for seven players to be played on a mainframe computer. Each player takes on a different role and together they must cooperate to control a star ship. The roles include simulation controller, communications, navigation, science, engineering, medical and helm. On their respective terminals players will see information displayed related to their role as they together explore the galaxy. There are no specific goals nor end to the game and the goal is exploration itself.
title: Star Ship Simulation

description: Noughts and Crosses is a cybernetic version of Tic-Tac-Toe. On a three by three grid the player must get three of their marks in a row. The player plays the game against the computer. The computer knows the rules but starts out without having any strategy, but since the computer memorizes each match it will learn to adapt to the player's game and become a stronger and stronger player over time.
title: Noughts and Crosses

description: Card Sharp is a card game played against the computer. The computer will ask for a card of a given suit or value and the player must give the card to the computer. The caveat is that the player cannot see the deck of cards and thus has to memorize exactly which cards are left in the deck. Giving a correct card scores points, but giving the wrong card loses the player points. The player can peek at the remaining deck as well but this costs a lot of points.
title: Card Sharp

description: Mastermind is an implementation of the code breaking game. The player can choose the length of the code and then try to guess it. After each guess the player is informed of the amount of numbers in the correct position and those that occur in the code but are in the wrong position. Using logical deduction the player has to find out what the correct code is in as few guesses as possible.
title: Mastermind

description: Rendezvous features similar gameplay as the typical Lunar landing game, but a different setting. The player must rescue a companion that's floating in space. The player ventures out in space and can use a thruster to accelerate or decelerate in their direction with the goal of meeting up with the companion. The player has limited fuel to achieve their goal and risks also floating in space forever.
title: Rendezvous

description: BASIC Football Game is a text game that plays a game of soccer. Player input is limited. When the player's team gets close to the goal the player can determine how hard the ball will be shot at the goal. Depending on the distance to the goal and some other factors there can be various outcomes to the shot. At full time the player can decide to play again or not.
title: BASIC Football Game

description: Startrek Simulation Program is a Star Trek variant written in Tiny BASIC. The player commands the USS Enterprise and must hunt and destroy all Klingon battle cruisers in the galaxy. Stars, star bases and Klingons are randomly distributed throughout a galaxy consisting of 8x8 sectors. The player can use the long range scanner to find out the objects in the player's current and adjacent sectors. Short range scanners give more information about the current sector. Once a Klingon has been found the player can use phasers and photon torpedoes to destroy them. Any energy lost during the battle can be replenished at a star base.
title: Startrek Simulation Program

description: Air Defense Simulation is most likely the first game ever made to be (partially) run on a computer. The game possibly ran on a UNIVAC computer at some point and allowed the simulation of air defense in North America. This would allow the US Army to play out scenarios and find the best strategy to employ. The program was intended to speed up existing simulation games that were played out without the use of computers. Many elements of the game were still played on paper, but most of the calculations were done by a computer to speed everything up. Modeled elements of war present in this game are enemy aircraft, anti-aircraft guns and naval guided missiles in a three dimensional grid.
title: Air Defense Simulation

description: Stratspiel I is a computer assisted wargame used by the US Air Defense that allowed the army to build a strategy in case of a Soviet strategic nuclear attack. The game played both during and after the attack and included air defense.
title: Stratspiel I

description: A Managerial Game for an Insurance Company is a serious game for internal training. It focuses on middle management and higher executive levels and looks at property and liability insurance. Tasks include planning and budgeting. It was first described in the Operations Research journal and was implemented as a computer game on the computers of the US company Allstate Insurance Company.
title: A Managerial Game for Insurance Companies

description: Decision Making Simulation: Model 6 is a serious game for training management decisions. The game is a sixth iteration and is meant for middle and upper administrative groups. The players run their companies and compete on a single market.
title: Decision Making Simulation: Model 6

description: General Management Simulation: Model 4 is a serious game for training management decisions. The game is a fourth iteration and is meant for middle and upper administrative groups. The players cooperate in large groups with multiple organization levels and run their companies and compete on multiple markets.
title: General Management Simulation: Model 4

description: Manufacturing Management Simulation: Model 1 is a serious game in which players cooperate to manage the manufacturing of their company. Each company has geographically separated plants. The plants share a common corporate office and raw resources to create different products.
title: Manufacturing Management Simulation: Model 1

description: Materials Management Simulation: Model 2 is a serious game in which players manage a company's materials. The goal is to satisfy preset sales demands at minimum costs. Goods include raw resources, finished goods and warehouse stock.
title: Materials Management Simulation: Model 2

description: Physical Distribution Simulation: Model 1 is a serious game in which players work together to manage the physical distribution side of a company. The company markets three different products and has eight warehouses, two distribution centers, and three plants. Products are shipped by truck, rail car, and airplane.
title: Physical Distribution Simulation: Model 1

description: Pitt-Amstan Market Simulator is a serious game in which a group of players manage a distribution outlet. The outlet serves 300 accounts of different types and sizes in a metropolitan setting. Three different product groups are involved (plumbing, heating and roughing in). The game supports play-by-mail.
title: Pitt-Amstan Market Simulator

description: Supermarket Battle Maneuvers is a serious game based around managing supermarkets. Players work together to manage their supermarket.
title: Supermarket Battle Maneuvers

description: Executive Decision Game No. 2 is a serious game used at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). Players group together to form different companies. Since the game is played mostly in classrooms corporate espionage is possible through eavesdropping. A business year is generally simulated every two hours of play.
title: Executive Decision Game No. 2

description: Executive Decision Game No. 3 is a serious game in which groups of players make executive decisions for their company, run by the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). The game is computer administrated but is to be played by mail. The game emphasizes mathematical and statistical analysis of complex problems.
title: Executive Decision Game No. 3

description: The Task Manufacturing Game is a serious game played on the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). The game simulates an entire business from individual employees, machines, customers to vendors. Players work cooperatively to make changes to the company, which includes redoing scenarios with adjusted input. The game can also play fully automatically without human input.
title: The Task Manufacturing Game

description: Management Game is a serious game played at the Carnegie Institute of Technology. Players work together in companies and try to successfully run a company in the detergent industry. Up to three different products are marketed in four regional markets. Products are manufactured from seven different raw materials. A game generally covers 30 to 50 turns of a month to simulate the long term effect of decisions.
title: Management Game

description: Marketing Strategy Simulation: Exercise III is a serious game in which players work together to formulate marketing strategies for their companies trying to optimize performance and outdo other companies played by other players.
title: Marketing Strategy Simulation: Exercise III

description: Harbus 2 Business Simulation Model is a serious game in which players manage a mid-sized company. Players work together to make decisions for their company and can set out guidelines. The computer will keep playing even if players do not input new commands, basing play on earlier guidelines. The simulated market features thirty customers over three regions. Companies can market three or four products. Factories have different departments that can be used for either parallel or service production.
title: Harbus 2 Business Simulation Model

description: A.S.C.O.T. (Analogue Simulator Competitive Operational Tactics) is an educational game program running on a custom-built computer at the Imperial Oil Company of Canada. The game teaches players to market their products at a service station. Players compete between stations and players working at the same station can either have a manager and helper structure or a partnership.
title: A.S.C.O.T.

description: Executive Decision Simulation is a serious game in which players work together in companies and make executive decisions. The game is designed for both actual executives as students as a training tool.
title: Executive Decision Simulation

description: Bank Management Simulation is a serious game that teaches players how to manage a bank. The bank holds $50 million in assets which need to be made profitable. The tasks for the players include considering market trends, and changing interest rates, service charges, administrative requirements, advertising and promotion, and more. The goal is to find the most profitable use of the bank's assets.
title: Bank Management Simulation

description: Management Decision-Making Laboratory is a serious game used in development programs and colleges. It uses a generic market in which up to three companies can compete. Players working for a company make decisions in regards to pricing, advertising, transportation and other fields in order to market their products in four different markets of which one is their home market and the fourth market is a competitive market (since none of the three companies has their home market there). Decisions are made on a quarterly basis and take ten to fifteen minutes.
title: Management Decision-Making Laboratory

description: Production-Manpower Decision Game is a serious game in which players work for a paint manufacturing company. The players compete together against the computer which follows a predefined set of rules. Decisions have to be made about payrolls, overtime costs, hiring staff, layoffs and inventory.
title: Production-Manpower Decision Game

description: Retail Management Game is a serious game in which players start with an operation that's running at a loss. Players in each company must work together to turn their twenty products (in two categories) around to make the company profitable again.
title: Retail Management Game

description: M.I.T. Marketing Game is a serious game in which players run companies selling standard and deluxe floor waxers. Each company develops a product and must price, distribute and promote it. Despite the involvement of a computer, an experienced referee is required to judge and evaluate the effectiveness of each company's strategy.
title: M.I.T. Marketing Game

description: Investment Game is a serious game in which university students deal, invest, promote stocks and other over-the-counter securities in a simulated securities market.
title: Investment Game

description: Production Management Simulation is a serious game run at the Pennsylvania State University in which players work together to run a company. Players need to handle hiring, firing, training, worker assignments, production scheduling (on two machine groups), allocation of expenditures, maintenance, quality control, and material purchasing.
title: Production Management Simulation

description: S.M.A.R.T. (System Managers Administrative Rating Test) is a serious game in which players hire and assign employees of different productivity to different roles and projects. Players work together in a single company and try to outperform other companies in a non-interactive way.
title: S.M.A.R.T.

description: Wharton Executive Game is a serious game in which players take executive decisions to run a manufacturing company and compete against other companies run by other players.
title: Wharton Executive Game

description: Decision Exercise is a serious game intended for top and middle managers. The game starts offline with participants being given study material and enough time to study the material. The game then comes in a form of a report to the board of directors in which other players are part of the board.
title: Decision Exercise

description: Sales Management Simulation Exercise is a serious game used to train sales managers. Players work for a company that sells perishable products with a high fixed production cost. The simulation includes the concept of how much time the actual sale's manager has so only limited actions can be taken in each period of simulated play.
title: Sales Management Simulation Exercise

description: Automobile Dealer Game is a serious game in which players manage an automobile dealer. Players in different companies compete in an interactive market.
title: Automobile Dealer Game

description: Manufacturing Management Simulation is a serious game in which players manage a manufacturing company. Emphasis lies on raw material purchasing, production, personnel management and goods distribution. Multiple players work for the same company and compete against other companies, but there's no direct interaction between companies.
title: Manufacturing Management Simulation

description: Marketing Management Simulation is a serious game in which players cooperate and compete to sell products. The game has been used for internal training at Remington-Rand, for the US National Sales Executives training course, and for training at Columbia University. Players work for different companies that compete together on the same market.
title: Marketing Management Simulation

description: Rohr Management Development Decision Simulation is a serious game in which the players manage aircraft manufacturing companies. Companies bid on contracts and raw resources required to build the aircraft and missiles required for the contracts. Players must factor in the costs of their personnel, material, inventories, research and development, investments of new operation plants, etc.
title: Rohr Management Development Decision Simulation

description: STEPS: Model 1 (Staff Training Exercise for Programming Supervisors) is a serious game in which programming supervisors are trained in management efficiency and decision-making. Players work together in different companies, but events in one company can influence the others.
title: STEPS: Model 1

description: Management Game for the Petroleum Industry is a serious game that provides a mathematical model of the petroleum economy. Players run different companies and compete on the market, although their actions do not further influence the market. A larger share of the economy is simulated, including production, refining, marketing, and administration. It's based on the economy of 1947-1958. The players run companies that sell various oil products in retail, wholesale and unbranded jobber markets.
title: Management Game for the Petroleum Industry

description: Airline Operating Game is a serious game in which players operate an airliner. The game is based on an earlier pen and paper game called Monopologs. The players have to efficiently run their companies, which includes purchasing, repairs, resource allocation and finances.
title: Airline Operating Game

description: Airline Sales Game is a serious game in which players must schedule flights and manage the provisions such as the amount of seats for tourists and first class on each flight. The goal is to meet certain sales goals.
title: Airline Sales Game

description: General Airline Game is a a serious game which combines the factors of both Airline Operating Game and Airline Sales Game. Players work together in larger companies and compete with other players in other companies in a larger market.
title: General Airline Game

description: The Travelers Management Decision Game is a serious game that simulates top management decisions in the insurance industry. Players form companies that compete with each other in an interactive market. Each year is a turn in which five decisions must be made in regards to: security investment, operating assets investment, marketing expenditure, underwriting control, and rates. The market itself will slowly get bigger, but the companies' individual decisions will determine who manages to control the biggest share of the market.
title: The Travelers Management Decision Game

description: Management Game for the Natural Gas Transmission Industry is a serious game in which middle managers take the role of players and are trained for making top-management executive decisions. Players work for different companies as the board of directors and have to make choices about long-term contracts, regulatory agency control, capital requirements, tax, depreciation, financing (long and short term), and subsidiary investment.
title: Management Game for the Natural Gas Transmission Industry

description: LOGSIM-WC (Logistical Simulation Wholesale Computer-assisted) is a serious game used by the US Army as a simulation for logistics. The game is intended to be played by higher administration, senior officers and civilians involved in the supply chain. The game simulates the operation of a National Inventory Control Point and measures the effectiveness of the supply by the players.
title: LOGSIM-WC

description: Fort Simulation U. S. A. is a serious game in which players manage a fort for the US Army. It teaches players about resource distribution, utilization and performance evaluation in relation to a Class I Army Installation.
title: Fort Simulation U. S. A.

description: University of Texas Small Business Game is a serious game for college students and small to medium sized business owners. Players are faced with competitive and operational problems in a manufacturing company producing industrial goods. Decisions allow the introduction of new products and extending to new market areas.
title: University of Texas Small Business Game

description: Top Management Decision Game is a serious game designed for graduate students at the College of Business Administration at the University of Washington. Players work together for a company and compete against companies played by other players.
title: Top Management Decision Game

description: Business Simulator is a serious game in which players run a company that manufactures and sells electric generators. Each company in the game is designed to be similar to Westinghouse Electric Company. Multiple players work together to run each company.
title: Business Simulator

description: 6000 Series Baseball Game is a basic baseball game. The pitcher throws the ball and the player must try to swing the bat at the right moment after which the players start running. The game uses a top-down view of the baseball pitch. The game is divided in nine innings.
title: 6000 Series Baseball Game

description: A Maze Game was demonstrated at RCA Laboratories' David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton in 1967. The game ran remotely on a DEC mainframe computer and was displayed onsite using a Tektronix Storage Oscilloscope. In the game the player could generate an ever increasing line on the oscilloscope screen. The line could be made to grow horizontally or vertically by the player with the aim to create a path navigating a maze.
title: Maze Game

description: Programming Proverbs is a book which outlines rules to improve the structure and readability of written code. The book was initially released with examples for programming languages such as BASIC, ALGOL 60, FORTRAN, COBOL and PL&I, but later editions were also released focusing solely on BASIC or PASCAL. The book contains one fully written game as an example: Kriegspiel Checkers. A checkers game in which two players play a variant of the traditional board game. The game plays mostly like normal checkers game except each player can only see their own pieces. The game is won either because of the normal checkers win conditions or because a player kinged one of the pieces by reaching the other side. The computer works a referee telling players whether their proposed moves are legal.
title: Programming Proverbs

description: Kriegspiel is a variant of Chess sporting incomplete information. Normal chess rules apply, with each player controlling 16 pieces of an 8x8 tile board. Where normally each player can see their opponent's move, here the players don't see the moves made by their opponent. The computer arbitrates the game since neither player is now aware whether a move they make is actually valid. If a player tries to make a move that isn't valid (for example because it would put them in a 'check' position) both players are informed that an invalid move was attempted. When a piece is taken the capturing player is not told what type of piece it was. Players can ask the game if any of their pawns are in a position that they can capture another piece. If possible they are then forced to make such a move.
title: Kriegspiel

description: Brands is a text-based Formula One racing game written in Standard BASIC. The player must race two laps at the short course at Brands Hatch Circuit. The player receives textual descriptions of the race track and must provide the gear to switch to and the amount of breaks and throttle to apply. If the rev limit of the car is exceeded six times the car's engine blows up.
title: Brands

description: Solitaire is a video game representation of Klondike solitaire designed for the PLATO system. In addition to keyboard control, it also supports the PLATO touch screen input.

sample_screenshots.caption: Title screen.
Starting a new game.
Finishing a hand.
Playing a hand.

title: Solitaire

description: Monabus is a business simulation game. The game is played with an entire class and each student takes on the role of a member of top management in a company. The simulation simulates three firms in a single industry. The firms initial position (funds, inventory, plant capacity) are identical. The goal is to be the most profitable company after a series of management decisions over one fiscal year.
title: Monabus

description: Lord is a text adventure in which the player explores 550 locations. The setting is Middle-Earth, from The Lord of the Rings, but it's not officially licensed. It also includes fantasy elements from other sources.
title: Lord

description:
Underground is a text adventure game in which the player explores a set of underground caves. The game's locations are described using text only and the player inputs commands with nouns and verbs. The goal is to accumulate treasure.

The game uses both science-fiction and fantasy elements in its setting. The player encounters a robot, a computer, a sorceress, gnomes and multiple animals. Puzzles require the player to use items and elements of the environment to their advantage.
title: Underground

description: Combat is a tactical space simulation game for up to nine players. Players fly around space trying to hunt down the other players and destroy them. The game takes place in a two dimensional universe. The game shares similarities to Star Trek. Players use sensors to locate each other and can raise shields and fire lasers and missiles when in combat. Players can send text messages to all or specific other players. The game is fully text-based. The game ran on the Minnesota Educational Research Institute Time Sharing System (MERITSS).
title: Combat

description: Nuchess is a chess program. The program is written in Fortran and requires a 64-bit architecture. It uses brute force to evaluate moves.
title: Nuchess

description: Haunt is a text adventure game in which the player explores a haunted mansion. The player must find treasure to score points, and find a way to escape the house. The player inputs text statements in the form of a noun and a verb to interact with the environment and the objects therein. The environment and consequences is described verbally to the player. The house is divided into multiple rooms which can be visited. Puzzles can often lead to death.
title: Haunt

description: Cube is a chess program. The program is written in FORTRAN IV and ran on a Cray-1 computer while competing at the 1980 and 1981 North American Computer Chess Championships.
title: Cube

description: Clash is a chess program written in Fortran IV. The program competed at the 1980 North American Computer Chess Championship and ranked last place. The program ran on the Texas Instruments TI-990 mini computer.
title: Clash
